questions.text: A child presents to the OPD with a mild cold. On examination, he is found to have adenoid facies. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Adenoid facies is a characteristic look seen in chronic adenoiditis. The treatment of choice in chronic adenoiditis is adenoidectomy with coblation.

Clinical features:

  • Nasal obstruction is the most common symptom. This leads to mouth breathing. Nasal obstruction also interferes with feeding or suckling in a child. As respiration and feeding cannot take place simultaneously, a child with adenoid enlargement fails to thrive.
  • Nasal discharge, sinusitis, and epistaxis.
  • Bilateral conductive hearing loss and serous otitis media due to eustachian tube obstruction.
  • Rhinolalia clausa - hyponasal voice.
  • Adenoid facies - elongated face with a dull expression, pinched up nose, absent nasolabial crease, open mouth, prominent and crowded upper teeth.
  • Sleep apnoea - chronic cases lead to hypoxemia and pulmonary vasoconstriction. This consequently leads to pulmonary hypertension and cor pulmonale.
  • Aprosexia - lack of concentration.

Management:

Definitive management is adenoidectomy. The treatment of choice is coblation adenoidectomy because it removes the tissue and prevents hemorrhage via radiofrequency ablation while curettage and microdebridement needs further cauterisation to control bleeding points. Older methods of classical adenoidectomy via mouth has been replaced by these newer techniques as the older methods were blind procedure

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric department with severe pain in the hands and feet. On examination, corneal opacities and telangiectatic skin lesions on the thighs were observed. On further investigation, he is found to be deficient in α-galactosidase A enzyme. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is Fabry disease.

Fabry disease is an X-linked inborn error of glycosphingolipid metabolism due to deficient activity of α-galactosidase A enzyme. This enzyme deficiency leads to accumulations of neutral glycosphingolipids, primarily globotriaosylceramide, especially in the plasma and lysosomes of vascular endothelial and smooth muscle cells, cardiac myocytes, and renal podocytes.

Features of Fabry disease:

  • Angiokeratomas - telangiectatic skin lesions characteristically seen densest between the umbilicus and knees called the bathing trunk area
  • Hypohidrosis - decreased sweating
  • Corneal and lenticular opacities
  • Painful acroparesthesias 
  • Fabry crises - severe agonizing pain in the hands, feet, and proximal extremities
  • Urinary examination shows lipid inclusions with birefringent Maltese cross

Arrhythmias, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and heart failure are some of the important cardiovascular manifestations. The most common valvular lesion is mitral insufficiency. Cardiac arrhythmias may result in transient ischemic attacks and stroke. Renal failure, characterized by proteinuria, isosthenuria, azotemia, and gradual deterioration of renal function, is seen. Renal failure, cardiac disease, or stroke are the major causes of mortality in patients with Fabry disease.

Below is the image of angiokeratomas distributed along the bathing trunk area.

Other options:

Option A- Niemann-Pick disease is a lysosomal storage disorder with deficient activity of acid sphingomyelinase. It has an autosomal recessive mode of inheritance. It leads to the accumulation of sphingomyelin in the monocyte-macrophage system. The clinical features include a combination of hepatosplenomegaly, developmental delay, reticular or nodular infiltration in the lungs, and retinal cherry-red spots.

Option B- Tay-Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disorder with a deficiency of β-hexosaminidase. It has an autosomal recessive mode of inheritance. It leads to the accumulation of GM2 gangliosides, preferentially in the central nervous system. Affected children present with seizures, developmental delay, increased startle response, macrocephaly, and cherry-red spots in the eye. 

Option D- Gaucher disease is a lysosomal storage disorder with a deficiency of acid-β-glucosidase. It has an autosomal recessive mode of inheritance. It leads to the accumulation of glucosylceramide in the reticuloendothelial system. The features of this disease include growth retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, anemia, and Erlenmeyer flask deformity of the distal femur. Histology shows the presence of Gaucher cells, a characteristic wrinkled-paper appearance resulting from the presence of intracytoplasmic substrate inclusions. The intelligence of the child is normal.

questions.text: Which of the following thyroid neoplasia arise from the parafollicular c cells of thyroid?
questions.solution:
Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid (MTC) arises from the parafollicular C cells. Most of MTC are sporadic. Some are associated with inheritable syndromes like familial MTC, MEN2A, and MEN2B, all of which are secondary to RET gene mutations.

Most patients present at 50–60 years and have a female preponderance. MTC secretes calcitonin, carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), and adrenocorticotrophic hormone (ACTH).

Features of MTC

  • Painful neck mass with cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Dysphagia, dysphonia, or dyspnea if there is local invasion
  • Diarrhoea due to increased intestinal motility
  • Cushingoid habitus due to ectopic ACTH production
  • Blood-borne metastasis 

 

Microscopically, they consist of sheets of neoplastic cells separated by collagen and amyloid stroma. Raised calcitonin and CEA levels, and fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the mass helps in diagnosis.

 

Related Pearl: Follicular thyroid malignancy

More common in iodine-deficient areas

Mean age of presentation is 50 years

Commonly present as solitary thyroid nodules

FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions

Malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion

Associated with P53, PTEN, PAX/PPAR-gamma, RAS 

miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346) are associated with follicular carcinoma

Histology:

  • Usually solitary lesion
  • Encapsulated
  • Has uniform micro follicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid
  • Capsular and vascular invasion indicates malignancy
  • Tumor thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Vascular (hematogenous) dissemination is common, with metastases to bone, lungs, liver, and elsewhere.

The prognosis depends largely on the extent of invasion and stage at presentation.

Serum thyroglobulin levels are used for monitoring tumor recurrence because this thyroid protein should be barely detectable in a patient who is free of disease.

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

  • Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma.
  • Most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 
  • Mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade; more common in women than men (2:1)
  • Usually cold nodule on the scan
  • Branching papillae and follicles with the fibrovascular stalk, Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes: Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei, pseudo-inclusions, nuclear grooves.
  • Lymph node metastasis is common
  • Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma.
  • Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion
  • Most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain
  • Excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

questions.text: A neonate was diagnosed with meningitis. The organism showed resistance to bacitracin. What is the most likely cause for this neonate's condition?
questions.solution:
Streptococcus agalactiae is a group B streptococci that shows β-hemolysis on blood agar, is resistant to bacitracin, and gives a positive CAMP test.

S. agalactiae is a capsulated Gram-positive coccus occurring in chains. It causes meningitis in the neonatal period. Infection is commonly acquired from the maternal vagina during birth. There are two clinical types seen in neonates:
  • Early-onset type (more common) presents within a week of birth as meningitis or septicemia and is often fatal.
  • Late-onset type presents between the second to twelfth week of life commonly as septicemia.

The CAMP test (Christie, Atkins and Munch-Peterson) is used to identify group B β-hemolytic-streptococci based on their ability to form CAMP factor. This factor causes synergistic hemolysis with β-hemolysin formed by Staphylococcus aureus, when Streptococcus agalactiae is inoculated perpendicular to a streak of Staphylococcus aureus on blood agar. This produces the characteristic arrow-head zone of hemolysis.

The image given below shows a positive CAMP test.

The following table provides important laboratory characteristics which differentiate Streptococcus pyogenes from Streptococcus agalactiae.

Species Lancefield Group Typical Hemolysis Important Lab Characteristics
S. pyogenes A β Bacitracin sensitive, PYR test positive
S. agalactiae B β Bacitracin resistant, PYR test negative, Hippurate hydrolysis positive, CAMP test positive

The illustration given below shows the classification of Streptococci.

The classification of gram-positive organisms is summarized in the flow chart below.

questions.text: A pregnant couple presented to the OPD with concerns about thalassemia in their baby due to a positive family history. Genetic studies revealed that both she and her husband are carriers. What is the probability that the child will have thalassemia major?
questions.solution:
There is 25% probability that their child will have thalassemia major.

β-thalassemia occurs due to mutations causing an impaired synthesis of β-globin chains of hemoglobin (Hb), leading to anemia, hypoxia, and hemolysis. The mutations can be of two types:

  1. Absent β chain synthesis (β0)
  2. Reduced β chain synthesis (β+)

Being an autosomal recessive disease, disease occurs only when both alleles are defective. When only one is defective, they are called carriers or trait. Here as both the parents are carriers, their alleles will be β/β0 or β/β+ (1 β-thalassemia allele and 1 normal allele). As the clinical disease doesn't alter much based on it being β+ or β0, its safe to use use β+ to represent a thalassemia allele.

  β β+ 
β β/β β/β+
β+ β/β+ β+/β+

Thalassemia major means both alleles are mutated. And from the table, that can occur in one of the four ways possible. Hence the answer is 25%

 Clinical syndromes of β-thalassemia depending on the genetic defect:

Major: 

  • Severe microcytic hypochromic anemia with target cells, basophilic stippling, and fragmented red cells (typical Hb: 3 to 6 g/dL), requiring regular blood transfusions
  • Crewcut appearance of facial bones and skull (due to cortical bone erosion by expanding marrow and new bone formation)
  • Speen, liver, and lymph node enlargement (due to extramedullary hematopoiesis)

Minor: 

  • More common
  • Usually asymptomatic
  • Mild microcytic hypochromic anemia with target cells and basophilic stippling (important to rule out iron deficiency anemia by serum iron studies)
  • Mild erythroid hyperplasia in bone marrow

Other features:

  Major Minor (also called trait)
Genotype

β0/β0, β0/β+, β+/β+ (2 β-thalassemia alleles)

β/β0 or β/β+ (1 β-thalassemia allele and 1 normal allele)
Hb
electro-phoresis

HbF: Major Hb, markedly elevated

HbA2: Usually normal to low

HbA: Absent or present in small amounts

HbA2: Increased (4-8%) with an elevated ratio of δ-chain to β-chain synthesis

HbF: Normal or slightly increased

A third clinical syndrome of moderate severity is called β-thalassemia intermedia. The genotype in this type includes milder variants of β+/β+ or β0/β+ and does not require regular transfusions.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids can form oxaloacetate?
questions.solution:
The amino acid Aspartate can be converted into oxaloacetate through a series of enzymatic reactions.

Oxaloacetate is an intermediate in the citric acid cycle (also known as the Krebs cycle or TCA cycle), a key metabolic pathway in cells that generates energy through the oxidation of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins.

Aspartate can be transaminated (an amino group transferred) to form oxaloacetate, which plays a crucial role in linking various metabolic pathways, including the citric acid cycle and gluconeogenesis (the synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate sources).

Anaplerotic process is the replenishment of the intermediates of the citric acid (Krebs) cycle to replace the catalytic processes and to ensure the continuation of the cycle.

Transamination of aspartate to form oxaloacetate is one of these reactions.

Other anaplerotic reactions:

  • Carboxylation of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, which is catalyzed by pyruvate carboxylase. 
  • Glutamate and glutamine to α-ketoglutarate, a reaction catalyzed by glutamate dehydrogenase and glutaminase, respectively
  • Compounds that produce propionyl CoA can be then carboxylated and isomerized to succinyl CoA.
  • Pyruvate can be carboxylated to malate.

Entry level in TCA cycle

Amino Acids
Alpha keto-glutarate
  • Arginine
  • Histidine
  • Glutamine
  • Proline
  • Glutamate
Succinyl CoA
  • Valine
  • Isoleucine
  • Methionine

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis. Which of the following cannot be used to treat her condition?
questions.solution:
Bacterial vaginosis cannot be treated with erythromycin.

Bacterial vaginosis is a polymicrobial condition caused by an increase in a number of organisms such as Gardnerella, Haemophilus vaginalis, Mobiluncus and Mycoplasma hominis.

This is due to the alteration in the normal vaginal flora which causes a decrease in the number of lactobacilli. It mainly reduces the pH and has antibacterial action by releasing hydrogen peroxide.

According to Amsel's criteria, the discharge has the following characteristics. 

  • White milky non-viscous discharge, adherent to the vaginal wall
  • The pH of the discharge is more than 4.5
  • Fishy odor when mixed with 10% KOH. This is called the Whiff test.
  • Presence of clue cells-the epithelial cells has a fuzzy border due to the adherence of bacteria.
  • Decrease in the number of lactobacilli and increase in the number of Gardnerella and other bacteria.

Treatment: Metronidazole orally or as gel, or clindamycin gel. Other drugs that can be used include tinidazole and secnidazole.

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

  Bacterial vaginosis Trichomonas vaginalis

Candida albicans
Causative organism  Altered vaginal flora- increased concentration of Gardnerella vaginalis Trichomas vaginalis-parasitic infection Fungal infection
Etiology Increased vaginal pH Sexually transmitted Decreased immunity
Sexual trans-mission No Yes No
Discharge Fishy, thin, yellow Frothy, green Curdy, white
Symptoms Fishy odor, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning
pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5
Speculum No vaginal epithelium inflammation Strawberry cervix Inflamed-epithelium
KOH Positive Whiff test Whiff test can be positive. Pseudohyphae seen.
Wet mount Clue cells. No WBCs seen Motile trichomaonads, WBCs seen WBCs seen
Treatment Metronidazole or Clindamycin Metronidazole, treat partner also Oral or vaginal azole, no need to treat partner.

questions.text: The fundoscopy findings of a known case of HIV with low CD4 counts in shown below. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts "sauce and cheese" retinopathy, which is characteristic of cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis. Ganciclovir is the treatment of choice.

CMV retinitis is the most probable diagnosis as the patient is immunocompromised (transplant recipient) and the fundoscopy shows patchy areas of retinal necrosis with irregular borders and overlying retinal hemorrhages.

CMV retinitis is mainly of 2 types

Central CMV retinitis

  • Dense, white areas of retinal necrosis
  • Retinal hemorrhage in the areas of necrosis
  • Pizza pie or sauce and cheese appearance

Peripheral CMV retinitis

  • Less demarcated
  • Infection spreads along the vascular arcades in a brush fire-like fashion.

The serological assay is not informative in the case of the immunocompromised patient and PCR assay is the gold standard for diagnosis.
CMV mostly causes infection in immunocompromised patients such as transplant recipients and AIDS. The most common infections are interstitial pneumonitis, gastroenteritis, esophagitis, and retinitis. Apart from ganciclovir, valganciclovir, foscarnet, and cidofovir are approved for treatment of CMV retinitis in patients with AIDS.

questions.text: Which of the following cataract surgery prefers suturing with nylon 10-0?
questions.solution:
Suturing with nylon 10-0 is preferred in extracapsular cataract extraction.

In ECCE, a portion of the anterior capsule of the lens is removed, allowing extraction of the lens nucleus and cortex. This leaves the remainder of the anterior capsule, the posterior capsule, and the zonular support intact. The intact lens nucleus is then removed from the eye through a limbal incision. 

An anterior capsulotomy is followed by hydro dissection using a balanced salt solution. This helps to separate the corticonuclear mass from the capsule. Removal of lens nucleus and aspiration of the cortex is done using a two-way irrigation and aspiration cannula. An intraocular lens (IOL) is then implanted and the incision is then closed.

The newer techniques of cataract surgery like phacoemulsification, MICS and FLACS doesn't require a suturing either because they use self sealing incisions or doesn't require a long incision.,

Related Pearl: Different extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) techniques

Conventional ECCE

  • Incision: 10 to 2 o'clock
  • Anterior capsulotomy
    • Can opener’s technique
    • Envelope technique
    • Continuous circular capsulorrhexis

Manual SICS

  • Incision: 4-6 mm
  • A self-sealing sclerocorneal tunnel incision is made.

Phacoemulsification

  • Incision:1.5–2.4 mm
  • Phacoprobe and foldable IOL is used
  • Sutureless surgery is possible with self-sealing sclerocorneal tunnel or clear corneal incision.

questions.text: What is the treatment protocol for pulmonary tuberculosis in children?
questions.solution:
The treatment protocol for pulmonary tuberculosis in children in 2HRZE + 4HRE.

The treatment for TB is under 2 phases. 

  • The intensive phase consists of 8 weeks (2 months) or 56 doses of isoniazid (H), rifampicin (R), pyrazinamide (Z) and ethambutol (E)
  • The continuation phase consists of 16 weeks (4 months) or 112 doses of isoniazid, rifampicin, and ethambutol. only pyrazinamide is stopped

Pediatric cases are also treated in the same regime, under 6 weight bands. All adolescents up to 18 years and weighing less than 39 kg are treated as per pediatric weight bands. But children weighing over 39 kg are treated as per adult weight bands irrespective of age. Steroids are not a part of NTEP regime.

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments
H mono-resistant/ poly-drug resistant TB regimen Lfx R E Z for 6 months

6 months long

Oral drugs only
Shorter MDR TB regimen

Intensive Phase:

Mfx Bdq(6 months) Cfz Z Hh E Eto for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Mfx Cfz Z E for 5 months

9-11 months long totally

Injectables used in Intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months or longer) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs 

18-20 months long

Oral drugs only

This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

 

Criteria for patients to receive standard Drug Resistant TB regimen:

Standard Drug Resistant TB regimen Inclusion criteria Exclusion criteria
H mono-resistant/poly-drug resistant TB regimen Isoniazid resistant TB with rifampicin sensitive No specific criteria
Shorter MDR TB regimen Patient with rifampicin resistant pulmonary or extra pulmonary TB Non drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • Pregnancy
  • Any extra pulmonary disease in PLHIV
  • Disseminated meningeal or central nervous system TB
  • Intolerance to any drug in the shorter MDR TB regimen
Drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • If DST/DRT result for FQ or SLI is resistant (XDR TB)
  • Presence of InhA mutation

questions.text: 2 medical students are conducting a study to see the effects of acclimatization at high altitudes. Which of the following will not be seen in the same?
questions.solution:
Hypoventilation is not a part of high-altitude acclimatization.

A person constantly exposed to high altitude slowly acclimatizes to the low PaO2 so that the deleterious effects of the same can be reduced. This occurs mainly via the following mechanisms:

  • Increased pulmonary ventilation
  • Increase RBC and Hb
  • Increased diffusing capacity of the lungs
  • Increased vascularity of the peripheral tissues
  • Increased ability of the tissue cells to use O2, despite low Po2.

Increased pulmonary ventilation: Low PO2 immediately stimulates the arterial chemoreceptors and causes increased alveolar ventilation. The immediate increase may blow off large quantities of CO2, lowering PCO2 and increasing pH which in turn may inhibit the brain stem respiratory centre via peripheral chemoreceptors. But this effect fades away in a few days and the respiratory centre activity returns to normal. Continued exposure to high altitude further increase the ventilation

Increase in red blood cells and hemoglobin concentration: Hypoxia triggers increased RBC production. Hematocrit slowly increases even up to 60%, and blood volume rises and together leading to hemoglobin and myoglobin rise

Increased diffusing capacity after acclimatization: Pulmonary capillary volume expands leading to an increased surface area of diffusion while an increase of pulmonary volume occurs which also increases the surface area of diffusion. Pulmonary arterial pressure rises leading to the opening of normally poorly perfused areas of the lung whereby diffusion further increases

Peripheral circulatory system changes during acclimatization: There is an initial rise in cardiac output to compensate for the low RBC and Hb which later falls to normal once these values rise due to erythropoiesis. Capillary angiogenesis occurs to improve blood flow, especially in the non-pulmonary tissues 

Cellular acclimatization. Changes also occur at the cellular level with an increase in numbers of mitochondria and cellular respiration in organisms living at high altitudes than the ones living at sea level.

questions.text: Which of the following is part of the WHO criteria for Severe Acute Malnutrition(SAM)?

choices.text: Mid-upper arm circumference less than 11 cm
Mid-upper arm circumference less than 12 cm
Mid-upper arm circumference less than 12.5 cm
Mid-upper arm circumference less than 11.5 cm

questions.solution:
Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is best defined as mid-upper arm circumference <11.5cm.

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in children of ages 6 to 59 months is defined by the WHO (World Health Organization) as any of the following:

  1. Weight-for-length (or height) below −3 SD (standard deviations) of the WHO Child Growth Standards
  2. Presence of bipedal edema
  3. Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) <11.5 cm

MUAC tape cut-offs:

Colour Measurements Indication
  Red   < 11.5 cm Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM)
 Yellow   11.5 to 12.5 cm Under-nourished
  Green   > 12.5 cm Normal

questions.text: What is the dosage of vitamine A prophylaxis needed in children aged 1-5 years coming from areas endemic to vit A deficiency?
questions.solution:
Children aged 1-5 years require 2 lakh IU of vitamin a every 6 months.

  • 100,000 IU is given with measles vaccine at 9 months
  • 200,000 IU is given with DPT booster at 15–18 months
  • 200,000 IU is given every 6 months (till 5 years of age)

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with nasal obstruction. On examination, an irregular mass was visualized in the nasal cavity.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Most likely diagnosis is antrochoanal polyp.

Antrochoanal polyp is a type of non-neoplastic nasal polypoidal masses of edematous nasal or sinus mucosa. It arises from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum near its accessory ostium, comes out of it, and grows in the choana and nasal cavity. It is usually single and unilateral which are more commonly seen in children and young adults. 

It has 3 parts namely

  • Thin antral stalk,
  • Round and globular choanal part, and
  • Flat nasal part.

The clinical features include unilateral nasal obstruction, mucoid nasal discharge, and a hyponasal voice.

A large polyp may protrude from the nasal cavity and may appear pink and congested. It is soft and can be moved with a probe.Anterior rhinoscopy may miss it when it starts to grow posteriorly. Posterior rhinoscopy may reveal a globular mass filling the choana and hanging down behind the soft palate.

Diagnosis is made by radiograph of the paranasal sinuses reveals opacity of the involved antrum. Non-contrast CT scan reveals the extent of the polyp. Endoscopic examination reveals the antrochoanal polyp hidden posteriorly in the nasal cavity.

Endoscopic sinus surgery is the treatment of choice. Recurrence is uncommon after the complete removal of the polyp.

Option A thornwaldt cyst is the persistence of pouch of lushka and is located at the midline on the posterior nasopharyngeal wall. It rarely presents as a mass protruding in the nasal cavity

Option B hypertrophic rhinitis is the inflammation and thickening of nasal mucose, submucosa, glands and periosteum. It doesn't present as a mass lesion

Option C deviated nasal septum presents with nasal obstruction, but no mass lesion 

Related Pearl: Antrochoanal Polyp

  • Main etiological factors: Infection and allergy
  • Usually affects children
  • Site of origin: Mucosa of the maxillary antrum
  • Clinical features:
    • Usually single and unilateral
    • Unilateral nasal obstruction which becomes bilateral when it grows posteriorly and obstructs opposite choana
    • Mucoid nasal discharge
    • Hyponasal voice
  • Findings:
    • Grows posteriorly and usually missed on anterior rhinoscopy
    • Posterior rhinoscopy: Globular mass filling the choana or nasopharynx
  • Investigation of choice: Nasal endoscopy. Shows nasal polyps that are pale, gelatinous and pedunculated
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

questions.text: A patient with a recent MI underwent coronary angiography, which revealed a block in the anterior interventricular artery. The infarction is likely to be present in which of the following regions of the heart?

choices.text: Anterior wall of the left ventricle
Inferior surface of the right ventricle

questions.solution:
The occlusion of the left anterior descending artery (LAD) will lead to the infarction of the anterior wall of the left ventricle.

The left anterior descending artery also called the anterior interventricular artery supplies the anterior 2/3rd of the interventricular septum and the adjacent anterior wall of the left ventricle.

Options A and D: The posterior interventricular artery supplies the posterior part of the interventricular septum and the inferior part of the right ventricle.

Option C: The left lateral surface of the heart is supplied by the circumflex artery.

questions.text: An infant was brought to the OPD with complaints of poor feeding and irritability. On examination, neck rigidity was present. Her sister has been on antitubercular therapy for 2 months. What are the CSF analysis findings expected in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with a neck stiffness and contact with patient of tuberculosis is suggestive of TB meningitis. The CSF picture is lymphocytosis, with low sugar and high protein

Tuberculous meningitis is the most severe form of tuberculosis.

Predisposing factors

  • Young age
  • Household contact
  • Recent measles
  • Protein-energy malnutrition

After the initial infection, the disease presents with vague symptoms accompanied by intermittent bacillemia. These feed the meninges forming Rich's foci. When the body's immunity is lowered during stress or coinfections, these ruptures cause widespread meningitis

Clinical Features

  • Prodromal phase: irregular fever, anorexia, irritability and occasional vomiting. These could last 1 to 4 weeks
  • The second stage has the nervous system involvement, with seizures, focal deficits and meningeal signs.
  • The third stage is one of coma and sequelae like Hydrocephalus (communicating or obstructive), decerebrate posturing, cranial nerve palsies, optic atrophy, extrapyramidal signs, and focal deficits.

Diagnosis:

  • CSP typically shows raised pressure, lymphocytic predominance, high protein, and low sugar
  • Imaging can show exudates and if present, features of the sequelae
  • The diagnosis is confirmed detection of tubercular bacilli in CSF. This can be by culture or cartridge-based tests like Gene Xpert

Treatment includes antitubercular treatment with two months of four drug-intensive therapy(HRZE) and 10 months of two-drug (maintenance) therapy  Sometimes, intravenous is dexamethasone is followed by oral administered for 8-12 weeks. This is to prevent sequelae of TB.. Patients with severe hydrocephalus may require shunts or ventriculostomy

questions.text: A male patient complained of visual disturbances. On examination, the light reflex is absent but the accommodation reflex is present. what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture where his pupils accommodate but do not react to light is called Argyll Robertson pupil. It is seen in neurosyphillis.

Features of Argyll Robertson pupil (ARP) are bilateral small pupils with the following characteristics:

  • Accommodation Reflex Present (ARP): Reduce in size on a near object (i.e., they accommodate)
  • Light Reflex absent: Do not constrict when exposed to bright light (i.e., they do not react to light).
  • This is an example of light near dissociation.
  • Seen in neurosyphilis, along with other features such as the following:
    • Loss of reflexes in the legs; impaired position and vibratory sense; Romberg’s sign; and, in almost all cases, bilateral Argyll Robertson pupils, which fail to constrict to light but accommodate.

Other causes of light-near dissociation are:

In unilateral eye

  • Adie pupil
  • Herpes zoster ophthalmicus
  • Aberrant regeneration of the third cranial nerve

In bilateral eyes

  • Type 1 diabetes mellitus
  • Myotonic dystrophy

questions.text: A newborn baby is brought to the OPD with complaints of noisy breathing. On performing Direct laryngoscopy, you notice the following findings.  Which of the following stridor is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the laryngoscopy image showing omega-shaped epiglottis is suggestive of laryngomalacia. Inspiratory stridor is seen in laryngomalacia.

Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital cause of stridor. It is characterized by excessive flaccidity of the supraglottic larynx which is sucked in during inspiration. This results in inspiratory stridor, a feature typical of laryngomalacia.

It presents just after birth and subsides by 2 years of age. Stridor is increased on crying but improves (decreases) in the prone position, and worsens during feeding or crying. The cry is normal.

Direct laryngoscopy shows an elongated epiglottis that is curled upon itself, making it appear omega (Ω)-shaped. Other features include floppy aryepiglottic folds and prominent arytenoids.

Stridor is noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through narrowed air passages. Stridor may be heard during inspiration, expiration or both

  • Inspiratory stridor is seen in supraglottic lesions. It is often produced in obstructive lesions of the supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi, e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.
  • Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.

Treatment of Laryngomalacia:

  • Mostly, it self corrects by 2 years of age.
  • Tracheostomy may be required for some cases of severe respiratory obstruction.
  • Supraglottoplasty is required in cases of severe laryngomalacia.

questions.text: A child is brought to the casualty with a history of dyspnea. His mother gives a history of foreign body aspiration. What is the first investigation to be done?
questions.solution:
The first investigation in a child with suspicion of foreign body aspiration is Xray.

Food items (nuts, seeds hard candy, gum, bones raw fruits, and vegetables) account for the majority of choking cases in children. The most common site of foreign body lodging is the bronchus. Foreign body aspiration into the airway has three stages: immediate symptoms of coughing and choking, an asymptomatic interval, and later complications such as fever, atelectasis, and pneumonia.

When a child presents with a history of choking, detailed history taking and physical examination of the nose, oral cavity, pharynx, neck, and lungs are necessary.

The next step for suspected foreign body aspiration is to obtain a chest X-ray, including the abdomen, despite most foreign bodies being radiolucent. Secondary findings on the X-ray can indicate foreign body involvement, such as air trapping, atelectasis, obstructive emphysema, asymmetric hyperinflation, mediastinal shift, or consolidation. While a CT scan has high accuracy, it is not typically performed due to radiation risks. 

The treatment of choice for a foreign body in the airway is its endoscopic removal with a rigid instrument, usually a bronchoscope, by a specialist otolaryngologist or pulmonologist. Bronchoscopy must be performed even if there is a high suspicion of an airway foreign body in spite of negative or inconclusive imaging.

questions.text: A girl is diagnosed with lead poisoning. Which of the following enzyme defects is the likely cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
The enzyme defective in lead intoxication is ALA dehydratase.

The most common cause of lead poisoning in children is seen due to lead paint which was used in the older times.

It is toxic because it can substitute for calcium in many fundamental cellular processes. It crosses red blood cell membranes as well as the blood-brain barrier and enters the neuroglia cells which support brain function.

The fatal dose of lead acetate is 20 g. The fatal period is 1-2 days.

questions.text: A patient was incidentally found to have essential fructosuria. Which of the following enzymes is deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
Essential fructosuria is due to the deficiency of the enzyme hepatic fructokinase, inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. Fructokinase is the first enzyme to act on fructose metabolism.

  • This defective degradation does not cause any clinical symptoms.
  • Fructose is either excreted unchanged in the urine or metabolized to fructose-6-phosphate by alternate pathways in the body, most commonly by hexokinase in adipose tissue and muscle.
  • No treatment is indicated for essential fructosuria.

Other options:

Aldolase A is an enzyme involved in glycolysis, catalyzing the conversion of fructose-1,6-bisphosphate to glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate and dihydroxyacetone phosphate. It is not directly related to fructose metabolism, so it is not deficient in essential fructosuria.

Aldolase B is another isoform of the aldolase enzyme family. Unlike aldolase A, aldolase B plays a crucial role in fructose metabolism. It catalyzes the cleavage of fructose-1-phosphate into glyceraldehyde and dihydroxyacetone phosphate. Deficiency of aldolase B is associated with hereditary fructose intolerance, a condition characterized by the inability to metabolize fructose. 

Sucrase, also known as sucrase-isomaltase, is an enzyme involved in the digestion of sucrose (table sugar) into glucose and fructose. It is primarily found in the brush border of the small intestine. Deficiency of sucrase results in a condition known as congenital sucrase-isomaltase deficiency (CSID), which leads to gastrointestinal symptoms upon ingestion of sucrose-containing foods.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with fever, cough, conjunctival congestion, and coryza. On examination, there are red maculopapular rashes on the neck and forehead. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of cough, conjunctivitis and coryza along with fever with rash leads to a diagnosis of measles.

Measles is a common cause of fever with rash that spread via droplets. Apart from the characteristic prodrome. it presents with Koplik spots I.E white grain lesions with surrounding erythema on the buccal mucosa opposite to the lower second molar. The rash macular rash of measles begins behind the ears on the 4th day, rapidly becomes maculopapular and spreads to the face, neck, chest, arms, trunk, thighs and legs.

Other options:

Option A: Mumps is caused by a paramyxovirus and spread by droplets and contact. It causes fever, malaise unilateral or bilateral parotitis. It also causes epididymo-orchitis in males.

Option C: Chickenpox is caused by varicella zoster and spreads by contact and airborne. It has a prodrome of fever, malaise, anorexia and headache which is followed by a rash in 1-2 days. It has pruritic erythematous macules that first appear on the trunk and spreads to face and extremities that evolve into papules, vesicles and pustules that become crusted. The presence of several crops of lesions that are in different stages of evolution is a characteristic of varicella.

Option D: Erythema infectiosum (fifth disease) is caused by parvovirus B19 transmitted by airborne route. The prodromal consists of low-grade fever, headache and mild upper respiratory tract infection. An erythematous slapped cheeked rash that first appears on the face is characteristic. A macular rash then spreads to the trunk and extremities that undergoes central clearing giving a lacy or reticulated pattern.

Related Pearl: Viral infections associated with rash

questions.text: What is the delivery criteria in a Type A PHC?

choices.text: It has more than 20 deliveries per month
It has less than 20 deliveries per month
It has more than 30 deliveries per month
It has less than 30 deliveries per month

questions.solution:
• Type A PHC has less than 20 deliveries per month.
  • Type B PHC has 20 or more deliveries per month.

    • Prevention and control of locally endemic diseases

    • Promotion of sanitation and testing of water

    • Basic laboratory services

questions.text: A patient presents with ascites and edema. On examination, JVP was elevated. Gross examination finding of the tissue biopsy is shown. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of ascites, and edema with elevated JVP points towards congestive hepatopathy. The image shows a nutmeg liver and chronic passive congestion of the liver. it usually occurs due to congestive heart failure.

Pathogenesis:

  • It is seen in patients with chronic cardiac lesions, especially those affecting the right heart (e.g., right-sided heart failure), which causes the blood to be damped back into the inferior vena cava and then into the hepatic veins.
  • This leads to increased pressure in the sublobular branches of the hepatic veins, which causes an engorgement of venous blood.

Gross appearance:

  • In chronic passive hepatic congestion due to heart failure, the centrilobular regions are grossly red-brown due to congestion and slightly depressed (because of cell death) and are accentuated against the surrounding zones of uncongested tan liver (nutmeg liver).
  • The appearance is called the nutmeg liver pattern due to its close resemblance with the cut surface of the nutmeg seed.

The image below liver with gross appearance as described above along with cut section of the nutmeg seed on top left corner.

Microscopic appearance:

Microscopic examination reveals centrilobular hemorrhage, hemosiderin-laden macrophages, and variable degrees of hepatocyte dropout and necrosis.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman was admitted for bacterial pneumonia with a pleural effusion. The pleural fluid analysis revealed a specific gravity of 1.031 and contained a large number of polymorphonuclear neutrophils. Which of the following best characterizes the pleural effusion in this patient?
questions.solution:
A specific gravity of 1.031 (>1.020) is suggestive of an exudate. The presence of a large number of neutrophils indicates a purulent exudate.

Purulent exudate is an inflammatory exudate rich in leukocytes, mostly neutrophils; the debris of the dead cells; and microbes.

Exudate:

  • Increased vascular permeability, caused by inflammatory mediators, may lead to the accumulation of protein-rich fluid called an exudate.
  • It has a high specific gravity of >1.020.
  • An exudate may be further classified into the following types:
    • Serous exudate: The exudative fluid does not contain microbes or leukocytes. Serous exudate is usually seen in spaces created by cell injury or into body cavities lined by pleura, pericardium, or peritoneum.
    • Fibrinous exudate: It occurs in inflammation associated with large vascular leaks and local procoagulant stimulus (Ex: caused by cancer cells). With a greater increase in vascular permeability, fibrinogen may pass out of the blood into the exudate. The fibrin formed is deposited in the extracellular space. A fibrinous exudate is characteristic of inflammation in the lining of body cavities, such as meninges, pericardium, and pleura.
    • Purulent exudate: It is an inflammatory exudate rich in leukocytes, mostly neutrophils; the debris of the dead cells, and microbes.

Transudate:

  • Transudate is extravascular fluid, which is essentially an ultrafiltrate of blood plasma. It results from increased fluid pressures or diminished colloid oncotic forces in the plasma, and not due to the increased vascular permeability.
  • It has low protein content and low nucleated-cell counts (less than 500 to 1000 per microliter) and low specific gravity (<1.012).
  • Noninflammatory edema and effusions (transudate) are common in many diseases, including heart failure, liver failure, renal disease, and severe nutritional disorders.

Related Pearl: Types of pleural effusion

Transudative Pleural effusion

  • Cirrhosis
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Peritoneal dialysis
  • Superior vena cava obstruction
  • Myxedema 
  • Urinothorax

Exudative Pleural effusion 

  • Neoplastic disease: metastatic disease and mesothelioma
  • Infectious disease

  • GI: Esophageal perforation, pancreatic disease, intraabdominal abscess etc.,
  • Collagen vascular disease: SLE, rheumatoid pleuritis, Wegener's, Churg Strauss syndrome etc.,
  • Post coronary bypass surgery
  • Asbestos exposure
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Drug-induced pleural disease: nitrofurantoin, dantrolene, bromocriptine, amiodarone etc.,
  • Radiation therapy
  • Hemothorax
  • Chylothorax

questions.text: Cardiolipin can be found in which of the following locations?
questions.solution:
Cardiolipin is the phospholipid found only in the mitochondria, in the inner mitochondrial membrane. 

It is essential for the following:

  • Optimal function of numerous mitochondrial enzymes that are involved in mitochondrial energy metabolism.
  • Maintenance of the structure of the mitochondrial membrane.

Clinical correlation:

Decreased cardiolipin or alteration in its metabolism results in mitochondrial dysfunction seen in Barth syndrome (cardioskeletal myopathy) which is characterized by an enlarged and weakened heart (dilated cardiomyopathy ), weakness in muscles used for movement (skeletal myopathy), recurrent infections due to small numbers of white blood cells (neutropenia), and short stature.

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerves does not carry parasympathetic fibers?
questions.solution:
The trochlear nerve does not carry parasympathetic fibers.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female, a known case of sickle disease came with complaints of unprovoked pain in the extremities and torso. A thromboembolic episode was suspected. What is the first drug to be started for prophylaxis of thromboembolic events in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of a sickle cell crisis. This patient with unprovoked pain in the extremities and torso most likely has a thromboembolic episode. The first drug to be started for prophylaxis of thromboembolic events is heparin.

The mainstay of prophylaxis of thromboembolic events lies in anticoagulant medication. The initial parenteral therapy with heparin, LMWH, or fondaparinux shifted to a novel oral anticoagulant like dabigatran with warfarin acting as a bridge drug, followed by a long oral monotherapy with rivaroxaban or apixaban for a few weeks.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of vertical diplopia upon climbing downstairs. On examination, he tilts his head on his shoulder while going downstairs. Which is the cranial nerve involved?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from a weak superior oblique and the cranial nerve involved in CN 4.

Vertical diplopia upon moving downstairs points towards a weakness in muscles used to depress the eye. The muscles used in the depression of eye are inferior rectus and superior oblique. The correction effort by the patient will be in line with the direction of action of the weak muscle. A correction effort my tilting head is in line with the direction of action of superior oblique (SO) muscle and so the cranial nerve involved in CN 4 which supplies the SO

 

There are seven extraocular muscles present in the eye. They are:

  • Levator palpebrae superioris - Which elevates the upper eyelids
  • Four recti muscles - Superior, inferior, medial, and lateral recti
  • Two obliques - Superior and inferior oblique

The muscles originate from the back of the orbit in a common tendinous ring called the annulus of Zinn and are inserted into the sclera.

All the extraocular muscles (including inferior oblique) are innervated by the oculomotor (III) nerve except:

  • Lateral rectus which is supplied by abducens (VI) nerve
  • Superior oblique which is supplied by trochlear (IV) nerve

questions.text: A neonate is brought to the pediatrician with complaints of bilious vomiting. The abdominal xray shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The radiograph shows the presence of a double bubble sign which is a feature of the duodenal atresia.

Duodenal atresia is the blockade of the duodenum caused due to the failure of the vacuolization of the solid duodenum.

It is associated with prematurity, Down’s syndrome, maternal polyhydramnios, etc.

It is usually identified during the prenatal ultrasound, where it shows the presence of a double bubble sign. If the atresia goes unnoticed during the prenatal period, the babies usually present with bilious vomiting soon after birth. Abdominal radiographs also show the double-bubble sign. It is treated by duodenoduodenostomy.

Other options:

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (option A) will show the presence of an enlarged gastric gas bubble (single bubble).

Jejunal atresia (option B) on an abdominal radiograph shows the triple bubble sign.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with recurrent episodes of spontaneous nasal bleeding. There is no history of trauma or fall. He gives a history of unilateral nasal obstruction and denasal speech. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is taken, which is shown below. What is this sign known as?
questions.solution:
The given CT scan showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus is called the antral sign or Holman-Miller sign.

The given clinical picture along with a CT scan showing the Holman-Miller sign is suggestive of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma commonly arising from the sphenopalatine foramen. 

From here, the tumor grows into the

  • Nasal cavity
  • Nasopharynx
  • Pterygopalatine fossa
  • Pterygomaxillary fossa
  • Infratemporal fossa

Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign but locally invasive tumor predominant in adolescent males in the age group of 10-20 years. It arises from the posterior part of the nasal cavity that is close to the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen. These patients have a hamartomatous nidus of vascular tissue in the nasopharynx that forms angiofibroma when testosterone appears. Therefore, it is thought to be testosterone-dependent.

Angiofibroma can extend into the nasal cavity causing obstruction, epistaxis, paranasal sinuses, pterygomaxillary fossa, infratemporal fossa, cheek, orbits causing proptosis, frog-face deformity, and cranial cavity. The clinical features include:

  • Profuse, recurrent, spontaneous epistaxis- most common
  • Progressive nasal obstruction and denasal speech- due to mass in the postnasal space
  • Conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion- due to obstruction of the eustachian tube
  • Sessile, lobulated, or smooth mass in the nasopharynx
  • Other clinical features include the broadening of the nasal bridge, proptosis, cheek swelling, involvement of IInd, IIIrd, IVth, and VIth cranial nerves

Diagnosis is based on the clinical picture. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is the investigation of choice that reveals anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus (antral sign/Holman-Miller sign) which is pathognomonic of angiofibroma as shown below.

MRI can also be done that reveals soft tissue extensions. Carotid angiography is also done which shows the extent of the tumor with its vascularity. The feeding vessels mostly come from the external carotid artery. In large tumors with intracranial extension, vessels come from the internal carotid system also. Biopsy of the mass is avoided due to the risk of bleeding.

Given below is a CT image showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus - antral sign or Holman-Miller sign.

 

Staging of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

Stage Spread
IA Limited to the nose and/or nasopharynx
IB Extension into ≥ one paranasal sinus
IIA Minimal extension into the sphenopalatine foramen with minimal part of pterygopalatine fossa
IIB Full occupation of pterygopalatine fossa with Holman-Miller sign, may with an erosion of orbital bones
IIC Extension into the cheek, temporal fossa, or posterior to pterygoids through the pterygomaxillary fossa
IIIA Erosion of skull base with minimal intracranial
IIIB Erosion of skull base with extensive intracranial with or without cavernous sinus

Treatment: Surgical approach is the treatment of choice. Embolization of the vessels can be done prior to surgery to reduce the risk of bleeding during the surgery. Radiotherapy, chemotherapy, and hormonal therapy can also be considered.

Other options:

Option A: Aquino sign is the blanching of the tumor mass in the glomus tumor when the ipsilateral carotid artery is compressed manually.

Option C & D: Hanging drop/tear-drop sign is characteristic of an orbital "blow-out" fracture, which represents the orbital contents herniating through the floor of the orbit into the maxillary antrum.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency room in a drowsy state after taking an overdose of his sleeping pills. His medical history includes insomnia for which he was on alprazolam. Which of the following medications will you administer to this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient is presenting with benzodiazepine (alprazolam) overdose. Flumazenil is the drug of choice for this patient.

Flumazenil is a competitive antagonist at the benzodiazepine binding site of the GABAA receptor. It antagonizes both the agonist (benzodiazepines) and inverse-agonist (beta-carbolines) of this receptor.

It is primarily indicated for the management of benzodiazepine overdose and the reversal of benzodiazepine anesthesia. 

Other options:

Option A: Naloxone is an opioid antagonist used in the management of opioid overdose.

Option C: Naltrexone, another opioid antagonist, is used in the management of alcohol dependence, prevention of relapse in opioid deaddiction after detoxification, and weight management. It might cause liver failure.

Option D: Nalmefene is a pure opioid antagonist with higher potency than naloxone. It is used for the treatment of opioid toxicity and substance abuse.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding STEP criteria of drugs?

choices.text: It is related to the various steps in clinical trial.
It lists out steps of drug metabolism
It helps to calculate volume of distribution of drugs
It helps to choose P drugs

questions.solution:
STEP criteria is mainly used to select P drugs.

P drugs or Physician's drugs or Personal drugs are those drugs that a physician is very familiar with and routinely prescribes for a specific disease. This concept includes the name, dosage form, schedule, and duration for a specific illness.

STEP here stands for 

  • Safety of the drug
  • Tolerability of the drug
  • Efficacy of the drug
  • Price of the drug

Selecting P drugs

  •  Define the diagnosis
  •  Specify the therapeutic objective
  •  Make an inventory of effective groups of drugs
  •  Choose an effective group according to criteria
  •  Choose a P-drug

questions.text: A patient had his molar teeth extracted following which, he developed loss of general sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Which of the following nerves is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
General sensation from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue is carried by lingual nerve, which is likely to be inujured in this case.

In the anterior two-thirds of the tongue,

  • General sensation is carried by the lingual nerve.
  • Taste sensation is carried by chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve.

In the posterior one-third of the tongue,

  • Both general and taste sensations are carried by the glossopharyngealnerve.

Valleculae is supplied by the internal laryngeal branch of the vagus nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following inhibits ferroportin?
questions.solution:
IL-6 inhibits ferroportin.

It is an inflammatory mediator  It stimulates the production of hepcidin from the liver and thereby inhibits ferroportin. 

Dietary iron is available in two forms - heme and non-heme iron. Initially, the ferric non-heme iron is reduced to ferrous iron by duodenal cytochrome B (ferric reductase) or by vitamin C. The reduced ferrous iron is then transferred into the enterocyte by DMT 1 (divalent metal transporter). 

Heme iron moves into the cytoplasm with the help of transporters. Here, it is metabolized to release ferrous iron, which then follows the same pathway as non-heme iron.

Once inside the enterocyte, it can either get stored as ferritin or transferred across the basolateral membrane by ferroportin. In the plasma, iron is transported in the Fe3+ form bound to transferrin, which is a transport protein. Hephaestin is a ferroxidase that oxidizes Fe2+ to Fe3+ before it is transported.

Hepcidin, an acute-phase protein secreted from the liver plays a major role in the regulation of iron absorption. When the body’s iron stores are adequate it downregulates the expression of ferroportin and thereby iron absorption too. Thus, iron is trapped in the intestinal cells which is eventually sloughed off. Hepcidin also inhibits the release of iron from macrophages by binding to ferroportin. High hepcidin levels are seen in systemic inflammation and low hepcidin levels are seen in hemochromatosis 

Iron is an important component of

  • Hemoglobin
  • Myoglobin
  • Cytochrome P450 groups of enzymes
  • Components of the electron transport chain
  • Ribonucleotide reductase

Given below is an image of iron absorption that shows ferroportin being inhibited by hepcidin at intestinal mucosal cells

questions.text: A 1.5 kg male baby was delivered vaginally at 32 weeks of gestation. The infant was cyanotic and required CPAP immediately after delivery. His chest radiograph is shown below. A deficiency of which of the following phospholipids in the lungs is the likely cause for the condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and chest radiography image showing diffuse bilateral opacities are suggestive of infant respiratory distress syndrome caused by a deficiency of dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine (dipalmitoyl lecithin). It is primarily seen in premature infants.

Dipalmitoyl lecithin/ Dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC) is a major component of lung surfactant. In DPPC, positions 1 & 2 on the glycerol are occupied by palmitate. 

Surfactant is secreted by the type 2 pneumocytes in the alveoli. It reduces surface tension at the air-liquid interface of the alveolus and increases compliance.

Other options -

Phosphatidylethanolamine, also called cephalin, is found in the cell membranes of nervous tissue, particularly in the brain.

Diphosphatidyl glycerol, also called cardiolipin, is found in the inner membrane of mitochondria and plays a key role in apoptosis.

Phosphatidylinositol present in the cell membrane acts as a precursor of hormone secondary messengers and platelet-activating factor.

Note - Lung maturity of the fetus can be assessed by determining the ratio of lecithin to sphingomyelin (L:S ratio) in the amniotic fluid. A ratio of >2 indicates maturity.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with hemarthroses of the knee joint and prolonged bleeding following tooth extractions. His platelet count and bleeding time are normal.  PT is within normal limits and aPTT is prolonged.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of hemarthrosis, a normal platelet count, normal prothrombin time (PT) and a prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) are characteristic of hemophilia A and hemophilia B. Specific tests for the blood clotting factors can then be performed to measure factor VIII or factor IX levels and confirm the diagnosis.

Hemophilia A is an X-linked disorder, caused by a deficiency of factor VIII. 

Other options:

  • In ITP, the platelet count is low and bleeding time is prolonged.
  • In functional platelet disorders, the platelet count is normal and bleeding time is prolonged.
  • In vitamin K deficiency, both PT and aPTT are prolonged; PT is usually relatively more prolonged than is the aPTT.

Related Pearl: Differences between Bleeding Disorders and Coagulation disorders

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, vomiting, and watery diarrhea. He gives a history of having consumed shellfish and raw seafood a day before. The causative agent showed the Kanagawa phenomenon on Wagatsuma agar.  What is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
Kanagawa Phenomenon is shown by Vibrio parahaemolyticus. The Kanagawa phenomenon is hemolysis on wagatsuma agar.

On Wagatsuma agar (High salt blood agar), pathogenic strains of V. parahaemolyticus are hemolytic, while non-pathogenic strains are non-hemolytic. This is due to a heat-stable hemolysin.

V. parahaemolyticus causes food poisoning due to the consumption of contaminated seafood, after an incubation period of 12–24 hours. The common sources of infection are raw seafood like mollusks and crustaceans. No enterotoxin like cholera toxin has been identified, it causes enteritis by invasion of the intestinal epithelium.

Clinically, patients present with nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, fever, and watery or bloody diarrhea. Fecal leukocytes are often seen in stool samples. Enteritis subsides spontaneously in 1–3 days with no specific treatment. Adequate hydration and electrolyte balance should be restored.

V. parahaemolyticus is a capsulated bacterium. It shows bipolar staining and has a tendency to pleomorphism. It is characterized by peritrichous flagella on solid media and polar flagella on liquid media and it gives a positive string test.

Pathogenic strains of V. parahemolyticus are hemolytic on Wagatsuma agar, while non-pathogenic strains are non-hemolytic. This is called the Kanagawa phenomenon and is due to a heat-stable hemolysin.

questions.text: Identify the hormones 1 and 2 in the following image
questions.solution:
The image shows the Hypothalamic pituitary axis and the hormones 1 is Inhibin and 2 is testosterone.

Hypothalamus stimulates the Anterior pituitary via GnRh to release FSH and LH.

LH stimulates Leydig cells to secrete testosterone, which in turn inhibits LH by a negative feedback mechanism. FSH stimulates Sertoli cells to secrete inhibin, which in turn inhibits FSH by a negative feedback mechanism.

Testosterone inhibits LH secretion by acting directly on the anterior pituitary and by inhibiting the secretion of GnRH from the hypothalamus. Inhibin acts directly on the anterior pituitary to inhibit FSH secretion.

FSH also stimulates the secretion of ABP (androgen-binding protein). FSH and androgens maintain the gametogenic function of the testes. Hypothalamic lesions in animals and hypothalamic disease in humans lead to atrophy of the testes and loss of their function.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male was diagnosed with Addison's disease. What is the steroid regime for this patient?

choices.text: Bolus of 100 mg, followed by 200 over 24 hours
Bolus of 200 mg, followed by 500 over 24 hours

questions.solution:
The steroid regime for Addison's disease is 100 mg bolus immediately followed by 200 mg over 24 hours. Acute adrenal insufficiency requires the immediate initiation of the following therapeutic strategies:

  • Rehydration - saline infusion at an initial rate of 1 L/h with continuous cardiac monitoring.
  • Glucocorticoid replacement - bolus injection of 100 mg hydrocortisone, followed by the maintenance dose of 100–200 mg over 24h.
  • Mineralocorticoid replacement - initiated once the daily hydrocortisone dose has been reduced to <50 mg as higher doses of hydrocortisone have sufficient mineralocorticoid action.

questions.text: Which  of  the following platinum based drugs are used in cervical cancer along with  radiotherapy?
questions.solution:
Cisplatin is the drug of choice for chemotherapy for cervical cancer.

The primary management for cervical cancer is chemoradiation therapy. This involves the combination of external beam radiation therapy, brachytherapy, and chemotherapy (usually with cisplatin). This approach has been shown to improve overall survival and reduce the risk of local and distant recurrence compared to radiation therapy alone.

Following chemoradiation, patients should be closely monitored for treatment response and potential side effects or complications. This includes regular physical examinations, Pap tests, and imaging studies as needed. The prognosis for stage IIB cervical cancer depends on various factors, such as the size of the tumor, lymph node involvement, and the patient's overall health. With appropriate treatment, the 5-year survival rate for stage IIB cervical cancer is around 58-63%.

Other Options:

Option A: Chemotherapy with doxorubicin is used in case of very aggressive recurrent tumors and residual tumors.

Option B: Trastuzumab is indicated for adjuvant therapy in early and metastatic HER2 positive breast cancer. 

Option D: Bleomycin is an anticancer antibiotic used for the treatment of squamous cell cancer and Hodgkin lymphoma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV-positive male presents with 2 weeks of cough, fever and night sweats. Investigations reveal  a CD4 count of <100 /μL. Which of the following infections is most likely to be seen in him?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette suggests opportunistic infection in HIV patients. The most common opportunistic infection when CD4 counts falls below 100 is disseminated mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infections

Mycobacterium avium complex, or Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare complex, is a group of slow-growing, nonchromogenic non-tuberculous mycobacteria. The infections occur in both immunocompetent and immunosuppressed patients. It is the most frequent organism affecting HIV and immunosuppressed patients, although about 40% of pulmonary infections occur in immunocompetent patients. Cervical lymphadenitis is the most common presentation in young children of age <5 years. Other manifestations include skin, and soft tissue infections, musculoskeletal infections, and disseminated disease

Treatment with either clarithromycin or azithromycin plus ethambutol is a preferred initial therapy along with starting anti-retroviral therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following ECG finding is characteristically found in Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome?
questions.solution:
Characteristic ECG findings in Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome is Wide QRS interval.

Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome is a form of atrioventricular reentry phenomenon characterized by the presence of accessory conducting pathways between the atria and ventricles that are separate from the AV node and Purkinje tissue. 

The tachycardia is usually produced by the conduction of a normal impulse from the ventricles to the atria via the accessory pathway (bundle of Kent). This is the orthodromic pathway. Less often, a premature atrial beat travels down the accessory pathway (while AV Node is still in refractory period) leading to premature ventricular activation. This is the antidromic pathway.

The classic ECG features in WPW are as follows:

  • A shortened PR interval (typically <120 ms)
  • A slurring and the slow rise of the initial upstroke of the QRS complex (delta wave)
  • A widened QRS complex (total duration >0.12 seconds)
  • ST-segment–T wave (repolarization) changes, generally directed opposite the major delta wave and QRS complex, reflecting altered depolarization 

 

Related Pearl: Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome

Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome (WPW) is characterized by an abnormal accessory pathway in the heart leading to arrhythmias.

Pathology- Born with an accessory pathway, the bundle of Kent which connects the atria and ventricle. The electrical impulses from the SA node reach the ventricles earlier via the accessory pathway as there is no AV nodal delay in this pathway. This leads to the preexcitation of the ventricle and initiation of ventricular contraction. This ventricular contraction is prolonged when the impulse via the AV nodal pathway reaches the ventricles.

Most common location of the accessory pathway- between the left atrium and free wall of the left ventricle

ECG changes:

Shortened PR interval- because of the early initiation of ventricular depolarization

Prolonged QRS duration- because of the AV nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.

Delta waves- slurred upstroke of QRS complex

The given ECG shows delta waves marked with red arrows:

Treatment:

  • Catheter ablation is the treatment of choice.
  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs like procainamide, amiodarone, quinidine, propafenone, dofetilide are used in slowing conduction in the accessory pathway (prolong refractory period).
  • IV procainamide is the drug of choice in a hemodynamically stable WPW presenting with atrial fibrillation.
  • DC cardioversion is done in hemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text: Which among the following carcinogens is  associated with hepatocellular carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Aflatoxin has high association with hepatocellular carcinoma.

Aflatoxins:

  • These are a type of mycotoxins produced by Aspergillus species of fungi, such as A. flavus (secretes B1) and A. parasiticus (secretes B1, B2, G1 and G2)
  • Frequently present in moldy foods, like groundnuts, corn, and peas.
  • These toxins are highly toxic to animals, birds, and human beings.
  • Known to cause hepatomas in lower animals, and carcinogenic effects in humans have also been seen.

Risk factors for HCC

  • HBV, HCV, aflatoxin, alcohol
  • Hereditary hemochromatosis, α1AT deficiency, Wilson disease, metabolic syndrome, and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.

Other options:

Option A: Arsenic is associated with carcinomas of the lung and skin 

Option C: Asbestos is associated with carcinomas in lung, esophageal, gastric, and colon

Option D: Benzene is associated with leukemia.

questions.text: From which structures do the alae of the nose develop?
questions.solution:
The alae of the nose develop from the lateral nasal processes. 

The development of various components of the nose can be summarized as follows:

  • Bridge - The frontonasal process 
  • Dorsum and tip - Fused medial nasal processes 
  • Alae - The lateral nasal processes 
  • Anterior nares (nostrils) - The original site of the nasal pit 
  • Nasal cavity - The nasal sacs formed by the elongation of nasal pits
  • Posterior nares (choanae) - Ruptured bucconasal membrane

questions.text: A newborn developed tachypnea and grunting immediately after birth. On examination, the baby was cyanotic, with a scaphoid abdomen. A chest radiograph was taken, which is shown below. Which of the following should be avoided in the management of this baby?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the x-ray showing herniation of the bowel loops into the chest and absence of bowel loops in the abdomen are suggestive of congenital diaphragmatic hernia. Bag and mask ventilation is to be avoided in the management of this baby.

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is a birth defect of the diaphragm. Malformation of the diaphragm allows the abdominal organs to push into the chest cavity, hindering proper lung formation and resulting in pulmonary hypoplasia. The most common type of CDH is a Bochdalek hernia and in most cases involving the left side. CDH is a life-threatening pathology in infants and a major cause of morbidity and mortality due to two complications: pulmonary hypoplasia and pulmonary hypertension.

Babies with CDH present with respiratory distress characterized by tachypnea, grunting, use of accessory muscles, and cyanosis. They may also have a scaphoid abdomen and increased chest wall diameter. Auscultation of the chest may reveal bowel sounds with reduced breath sounds.

Diagnosis: A chest radiograph and nasogastric tube passage can confirm the diagnosis of CDH. Prenatal diagnosis can be made using ultrasonography between 16 to 24 weeks of gestation.

Treatment:

The immediate step in the management is the naso- or orogastric tube placement for decompression. The airway is to be secured with endotracheal intubation (option B) and respiratory distress is stabilised. Bag and mask ventilation may increase the abdominal distension and limit the expansion of the hypoplastic lungs. Hence, bag and mask ventilation should be avoided.

Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) (option A) and high-frequency oscillatory ventilation (Option D) have been used as a part of the ventilation strategy to support respiratory failure. The main goal is to maintain oxygenation to the lungs and carbon dioxide washout without causing volutrauma.

Surgical repair of the defect is to be considered at least 48 hours after stabilization and resolution of pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: Which among the following functions is not carried out by the intestinal epithelium?
questions.solution:
Bile salts are not secreted by the intestinal epithelium. They are secreted by the liver.

The intestinal epithelium has multiple roles to be performed in the functioning of the gastrointestinal system.

  • Absorptive function: provides surface area and mechanisms for absorption of digestive products
  • Secretory function: intestinal digestive enzyme secretion
  • Protective function: both formation of the physical barrier and chemical barrier via the production of mucous

Bile salts are secreted by the liver from cholesterol.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with complaints of long-standing dacrocystitis. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for long-standing chronic dacryocystitis is dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) surgery. it involves removal of the bone adjacent to the nasolacrimal sac and suturing the lacrimal sac with the lateral nasal mucosa. This allows tears to drain directly from the sac via a new low-resistance pathway into the middle meatus.

Chronic dacryocystitis is a multifactorial disease affecting the lacrimal sac.

Clinical features can be divided into 4 stages.

  1. Stage of chronic catarrhal dacryocystitis: inflammation of lacrimal sac and blockage of nasolacrimal duct
  2. Stage of lacrimal mucocele: chronic stagnation and distension of the lacrimal sac forming a swelling
  3. Stage of chronic suppurative dacryocystitis: purulent discharge from punctum
  4. Stage of chronic fibrotic sac: thickening of mucosa to form a fibrous sac

Treatment 

Dacrocystorhinostomy (DCR) is the treatment of choice once local infection if present is controlled with topical antibiotics. it re-establishes the drainage

Dacrocystecomy is considered if DCR is contraindicated like in advanced age, TB or syphilitic infection of the sac

questions.text: Thyroid hormone acts via which among the following receptor?

choices.text: Transmembrane receptor linked to tyrosine kinase

questions.solution:
The thyroid hormone receptors belong to nuclear receptors. 

The nuclear receptor is a broad term that includes receptors located in both the nucleus and cytoplasm. This is because even for the receptors that are located in the cytoplasm, the end effect is seen via the nucleus.

Related Pearl: Classification of Hormones by Mechanism of Action

A) Hormones that bind to intracellular receptors

  • Cytoplasmic receptors
    • Steroids such as glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids and androgens
  • Nuclear receptors
    • Thyroid hormones
    • Vitamins A and D

B) Hormones that bind to cell surface receptors

  • GPCR - G protein-coupled receptors
    • Gs - stimulation of the 2nd messenger cAMP
      • Examples: ACTH, CRH, TSH, LH, FSH hCG, Catecholamines (β receptors), Vasopressin (V2 receptors), Secretin, Somatostatin, and Glucagon.
    • Gi - inhibition of the 2nd messenger cAMP
      • Examples: Catecholamines (ɑ2 receptors), Acetylcholine (M2, M4), Somatostatin
    • Gq - The 2nd messenger is Phospholipase C (IP3 DAG Ca2+)
      • Examples: Parathyroid hormone, GnRH - Gonadotropin-releasing hormone, GHRH - Growth hormone releasing hormone, TRH, Catecholamines (ɑ1 receptors), Vasopressin (V1 receptor), Gastrin, Cholecystokinin and Oxytocin.
    • cGMP as the 2nd messenger
      • Examples: Atrial natriuretic factor, Nitric oxide
  • Tyrosine kinase receptors such as those that employ Janus kinase (JAK-STAT pathway) or MAP kinase pathway
    • Growth hormone, Growth factors (GFs) - eg: IGF, VEGF, FGF, PDGF etc, Erythropoietin, Insulin and Prolactin.

Note: Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely to be seen as a side effect of lithium therapy?
questions.solution:
Tardive dyskinesia is not a known side effect of lithium therapy.

Tardive dyskinesia is involuntary movements of the tongue, lips, face, trunk, and extremities, usually seen in patients treated with typical antipsychotics (first generation) for more than a year. This may be reversible with early recognition and drug discontinuation. Treatment is with valbenazine, deutetrabenazine (VMAT2 inhibitors).

Known significant side effects of lithium therapy include

  • Polyuria-polydipsia 
  • Dry mouth 
  • Leukocytosis 
  • Headache
  • Hand tremors
  • Confusion 
  • Decreased memory
  • Muscle weakness
  • Hyperreflexia 
  • Muscle twitch 
  • Vertigo 
  • ECG changes
  • Nausea & vomiting
  • Diarrhea 

Related Pearl: Lithium in bipolar disorder

Guidelines for Lithium therapy
Indications:
Mania, hypomania, bipolar disorder, etc.

Blood levels of lithium:

For therapeutic purpose (treatment of acute mania) : 0.8-1.2 mEq/L

For prophylaxis (to prevent relapse of bipolar disorder): 0.5-0.8 mEq/L

Toxic levels of lithium: >/= 1.5 mEq/L
Contraindications:
  • CKD
  • Heart disease
  • Hyponatremia or diuretic use
Baseline studies:
  • BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen), Creatinine, Calcium, Urine analysis
  • Thyroid function test
  • ECG in patients with coronary risk factors
Acute adverse effects:
  • Tremor, ataxia, weakness
  • Polyuria, polydipsia
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Cognitive impairment
Chronic adverse effects:
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperparathyroidism

Related Pearl: Extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotic drugs
