questions.text: A patient was infected by Bacillus anthracis. Under which of the following bioterrorism categories does this organism fall into:
questions.solution:
Bacillus anthracis which causes anthrax is categorized under category A bioterrorism agent.

Bioterrorism is the deliberate release of an agent by attackers that causes one or more of a variety of different diseases. The agents of bioterrorism are classified into 3 categories:

  • Category A bioterrorism agents are those which are easily transmitted from one person to the other and are associated with high mortality rates and thus have the potential to cause major public health impacts. Examples include Bacillus anthracis, Clostridium botulinum, and Yersinia pestis.
  • Category B bioterrorism agents are those which are moderately easy to disseminate and are associated with moderate morbidity and low mortality rates. Examples include Coxiella burnetti and Brucella.
  • Category C bioterrorism agents are those which are emerging pathogens that could be engineered for mass dissemination in the future due to ease of availability, high mortality and morbidity rates, and ease of production and dissemination. Examples include Nipah and Hanta viruses. 

Related Pearl: Bioterrorism Agents

questions.text: Which among the following is false regarding papillary thyroid cancer?

choices.text: Most common age group is between 30- 50 years

questions.solution:
The wrong statement is option d. Calcitonin is the marker for medullary carcinoma and not papillary carcinoma

Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common thyroid malignancy with relatively good prognosis (option b) . It is more commonly seen in women between the ages of 30 and 50 (option a). Radiation exposure (option c) and a family history of thyroid malignancies are common etiologies. Genetic abnormalities in either the RET gene or the BRAF gene can be seen in papillary thyroid carcinoma.

Clinical features include an asymptomatic thyroid swelling with cervical lymph node enlargement. In advanced disease, there may be features like hoarseness, dysphagia, cough, or dyspnea. 

An ultrasound scan accurately assesses the size and number of nodules, as well as categorizes the lesions as benign, indeterminate, or malignant. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is a diagnostic test, helpful in investigating an indeterminate or malignant lesion.

Histopathology shows the following features:

  • Branching papillae
  • Orphan Annie eye nuclei: optically clear nuclei with fine nuclear chromatin
  • Pseudo inclusions: invaginations of the nuclear membrane
  • Psammoma bodies: concentric calcifications in the core of the papillae.

Below is the histopathological image of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid with characteristic Orphan Annie eye nuclei.

 

Papillary thyroid carcinoma is known to spread via lymphatics, hence lymph node metastasis is commonly seen.

Treatment of Papillary thyroid carcinoma is as follows:

Total thyroidectomy is the treatment of choice. Routine central neck dissection is not recommended. Neck dissection is indicated in higher-risk situations, such as

  • Tumor size > 4 cm (T3 stage) or gross extrathyroidal extension (T4 stage) or enlarged central lymph nodes - Total thyroidectomy + Central Neck Dissection
  • Lateral Aberrant Thyroid - Total thyroidectomy + Modified Radical Neck Dissection + Central Neck Dissection

For occult papillary cancer (<1 cm tumor size, with no lymphatic, vascular or capsular invasion) - Lobectomy can be sufficient.

Radio-iodine ablation is undertaken when a whole-body iodine scan is positive after a total thyroidectomy for any differentiated thyroid cancer (papillary or follicular carcinoma). 

The presence of any metastatic or residual thyroid tissue after total thyroidectomy can be detected by observing the uptake of radio-iodine in the entire body. To achieve effective uptake of radio-iodine, TSH levels need to be greatly increased, for example, by withdrawing thyroxine after the surgery for 4-6 weeks.

A positive whole-body iodine scan after total thyroidectomy indicates that there is either a metastatic or residual disease present. These patients are treated with I131 for radio-iodine ablation. 

A negative scan means there is no metastasis or residual thyroid tissue. They are followed up regularly with serum thyroglobulin, TSH and USG-neck.

questions.text: A patient is brought with symptoms of diarrhea, hair loss, and poor wound healing. Which mineral deficiency is responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The symptoms and clinical findings suggest a probable diagnosis of acrodermatitis enteropathica which is due to the deficiency of zinc.

It is an autosomal recessive disease due to a defect in zinc-absorbing transmembrane protein.

The symptoms are:

  • Growth retardation
  • Diarrhea
  • Alopecia
  • Rash involving the extremities, face, and perineum - rash is characterized by vesicular and pustular crusting with scaling and erythema
  • Gonadal atrophy
  • Muscle wasting
  • Impaired wound healing

questions.text: Identify the graph given below
questions.solution:
The graph shows a propagated epidemic.

A propagated epidemic is one in which there is a rise and fall in the number of cases multiple times with a gradual fall in cases overall. It occurs in infectious diseases where there is person-to-person transmission. Peaks repeat when there is a spread of infection to a different set of susceptible individuals. It continues till there are no more susceptible individuals or the chances of exposure to the disease or vector come down. It is common in communities where there are large aggregates of susceptible populations or there is a continuous supply of suseptible population by birth or immigration.

Related Pearl: Epidemics and its Types

Epidemics and its Types

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy.

Types

Common source epidemics

  • Single exposure or 'point source' epidemics
  • Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated epidemics

  • Person to person
  • Arthropod vector
  • Animal reservoir

Slow or modern epidemics

  • Non-communicable diseases

questions.text: Which of the following hormones have an inhibitory effect on hormone-sensitive lipase?
questions.solution:
Leptin and insulin inhibit hormone-sensitive lipase, whereas the other hormones given in the options stimulate it. 

Leptin is a hormone produced by adipose tissue in proportion to the amount of body fat. It acts as a long-term regulator of energy balance. It functions by signalling the brain, specifically the hypothalamus, to regulate appetite and energy expenditure. It suppresses appetite and increases energy expenditure to maintain body weight within a certain range.

In addition to its central effects, leptin also has peripheral effects on adipose tissue. Leptin inhibits hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) activity, which reduces the breakdown of triglycerides into fatty acids in adipocytes. This inhibition of HSL leads to reduced release of free fatty acids into the bloodstream, contributing to the overall regulation of energy storage and utilization.

Other options:

Option A: Glucagon is produced by the pancreas, glucagon stimulates hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) to break down triglycerides into free fatty acids, which can be released into the bloodstream for energy production.

Option B: Epinephrine is produced by the adrenal glands, and epinephrine is released during the body's stress response. It activates HSL, promoting the breakdown of stored fat to provide energy in fight-or-flight situations.

Option C: ACTH (Adrenocorticotropic Hormone) is produced by the pituitary gland, ACTH indirectly stimulates HSL activity. ACTH signals the adrenal glands to release cortisol, which can lead to the mobilization of fatty acids from adipose tissue.

questions.text: A female patient presents with nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and loss of smell. On examination of the nose, she has roomy nasal cavities, foul-smelling discharge, and dry greenish crusts. She is also found to have merciful anosmia. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of merciful anosmia, foul-smelling discharge, and roomy nasal cavities, with dry greenish crusts, points to a diagnosis of atrophic rhinitis.

Atrophic rhinitis is a chronic inflammation of the nose characterized by atrophy of nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. The exact etiology of this condition is not known. It is more common in females and starts around puberty. 

Clinically patients present with nasal obstruction, foul odor, and merciful anosmia. Merciful anosmia is when the patient has marked anosmia and is unable to smell the foul odor coming from their nose.

On examination of the nose, greenish or greyish crusting of the nasal passage, pale nasal mucosa, atrophied nasal turbinates, and epistaxis following the removal of the crusts. The roomy nasal cavity is seen due to the resorption of bones of the turbinates.

Treatment:

  • Nasal irrigation - using warm saline or an alkaline solution composed of sodium bicarbonate 1 part, sodium biborate 1 part, and sodium chloride 2 parts in 280 mL of water
  • Local antibiotics - Kemicetine antiozaena solution containing chloromycetin, oestradiol, and vitamin D2. 
  • 25% glucose in glycerine, estradiol spray, systemic use of streptomycin, potassium iodide, and placental extract.
  • Surgical management:
    • Young's operation.
    • Modified young operation.
    • Narrowing of the nasal cavity can be done by submucosal injection of Teflon paste, or by insertion of fat, cartilage, or Teflon strips under the mucoperiosteum.

Other options:

Option B: Nasal polyps are non-neoplastic masses of the edematous nasal or sinus mucosa. Nasal polyps can be antrochoanal polyps or ethmoidal polyps. They present with a polypoid mass in the nose.

Option C: Allergic rhinitis is associated with inferior turbinate hypertrophy and can cause chronic nasal obstruction. It is characterized by watery nasal discharge, sneezing, and itching in the nose.

Option D: Foreign body nose is commonly seen in children. The child presents with unilateral, foul-smelling nasal discharge.

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Atrophic Rhinitis

  • More common in females 
  • Usually starts at puberty
  • It is a bilateral condition
  • Symptoms:
    • Foul smell from the nose
    • Nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers due to large crusts filling nasal cavity
    • Epistaxis on removing of the crusts
    • Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements (merciful anosmia)
  • Signs:
    • Greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum
    • After removal of crusts, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates
    • Nasal mucosa appears pale

questions.text: Identify the maneuver shown
questions.solution:
The given image shows Pringle's maneuvre. It is a technique where the free margin of the lesser omentum is compressed to obtain rapid control of the hepatic artery and portal vein in liver trauma and surgery. The hepatoduodenal ligament is encircled with a vessel loop or vascular clamp to occlude hepatic blood flow from the hepatic artery and portal vein.This maneuver helps distinguish hepatic arterial and portal venous bleeding from hepatic vein bleeding, which will persist with the hepatoduodenal ligament clamped. In many cases, the liver laceration can then be explored and any actively bleeding vessels controlled with suture ligation.

4 P's in the management of liver injuries are:

  • Push : compression of the edges of the laceration
  • Pringle : applying pressure on the portal triad
  • Plug: the defects with silicon tubes
  • Pack : apply packs in and around the liver to arrest bleeding

 Other options 

Option a: Mattox maneuver refers to left medial visceral mobilisation done to visualise and repair the vascular injury in case of retroperitoneal bleeds near kidney

Option c: Cattell braash maneuver refers to mobilisation of right viscera, namely the colon, to visualise the superior mesenteric artery and repair bleed in infrarenal region

Option d: Liver hanging maneuver (LHM) is a method of liver resection by passing a tape between inferior venecava and liver to have adequate vascular control

 

 

Related Pearl: Relations of Lesser sac and Foramen of Winslow (Important)

Relations of Epiploic foramen

Anterior

Hepatoduodenal ligament containing Hepatic artery, Portal vein, and Common bile duct

Posterior

IVC, Rt.suprarenal gland, and body of T12 vertebra

Superior

Inferior

1st part of duodenum

Relations of Lesser Sac

Anterior

Caudate lobe of liver, lesser omentum, stomach, first 2 layers of the greater omentum

Posterior

Structures forming the stomach bed (pancreas, splenic artery, left kidney and suprarenal gland, the commencement of abdominal aorta & coeliac artery, left crus of the diaphragm, splenic flexure of the colon, and the transverse mesocolon)

Upper Border

Reflection of the peritoneum from the esophagus to the diaphragm

Lower border

Continuation of 2nd and 3rd layers of the greater omentum

questions.text: DNA is present in?
questions.solution:
Mitochondria are membrane-bound organelles found in eukaryotic cells. They have their own small circular DNA, known as mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), which encodes a limited number of genes.

mtDNA is inherited maternally and is essential for the synthesis of certain proteins involved in energy production through oxidative phosphorylation.

The presence of DNA in mitochondria is a key characteristic that distinguishes them from other cellular structures.

Other Options:

  • Lysosome: Cellular organelles containing enzymes that degrade cellular waste and foreign substances. 

  • Cytoplasm: Region within a cell that surrounds the nucleus and organelles. While some cellular activities occur in the cytoplasm, DNA is primarily housed in the nucleus of eukaryotic cells.

  • Endoplasmic reticulum: Complex network of membranes involved in protein synthesis, lipid metabolism, and calcium storage. It does not typically contain DNA.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department after a car crash. On examination, his BP was 80/40mmHg and pulses were feeble, neck veins distended, and heart sounds were muffled. Which of the following changes will you expect in the jvp of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and distended neck vein suggests a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. The JVP finding most likely to be seen is absent y descent.

Cardiac tamponade is the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space. It results in the obstruction of the blood flow into the ventricles.

This manifests as Beck's triad which consists of the following: 

  • Distended neck veins (due to decreased venous return)
  • Muffled heart sounds (fluid accumulation in the pericardial space)
  • Hypotension

The physical examination findings in a patient with cardiac tamponade are:

  • Tachycardia
  • Hypotension
  • Elevated JVP
  • Pulsus paradoxus

JVP will have a prominent x (early systolic) descent but an absent y (early diastolic) descent because of the limited or absent early diastolic filling of the ventricle. JVP is almost always elevated in cardiac tamponade and may be associated with venous distention in the forehead and scalp. There may be reductions in the amplitude of the QRS complexes, and electrical alternans of the P, QRS, or T waves in cardiac tamponade.

 

An eFAST is reliable and will show fluid in the pericardial space. A chest X-ray will show an enlarged heart shadow.

Cardiac tamponade can also be treated with open surgery procedures like sternotomy or left thoracotomy. This also allows for the heart to be repaired during the procedure. 

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: Identify the mode of inheritance from the pedigree chart given below.
questions.solution:
The pedigree chart shows an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance.

Autosomal dominant conditions are manifested in the heterozygous state, hence at least one parent of an index case is usually affected. In this mode of inheritance, both males and females are affected and both can transmit the condition. When an affected person marries an unaffected one, every child has one in two chance of having the disease.

questions.text: Which hormone is responsible for galactokinesis?
questions.solution:
Oxytocin helps in the ejection of milk by myoepithelial contraction also called galactokinesis

     Functions of oxytocin are:

  • Milk ejection (myoepithelial contraction)
  • ADH like action in high doses (reduces urine output)
  • Uterine contraction

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with renal tubular damage caused by one of his chemotherapeutic drugs. Which drug could it be?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of nephrotoxicity and is one of the dose-limiting toxicity of cisplatin therapy. Cisplatin achieves a high concentration in nephrons. Both direct toxicity and inflammation are responsible for nephrotoxicity. A high concentration of chloride stabilizes cisplatin and reduces nephrotoxicity. Therefore, chloride diuresis is used to reduce nephrotoxicity.

Cisplatin is a platinum coordination complex that enters cells by the high-affinity Cu2+ transporter CTR1 and thus degrade the transporter. Inside the cell, the chloride, cyclohexane, or oxalate ligands of the analogues are displaced by water molecules, yielding a positively charged molecule that reacts with nucleophilic sites on DNA and proteins.

Uses:

  • In combination with bleomycin, etoposide, or with ifosfamide and vinblastine, cures 90% of patients with testicular cancer
  • Used with paclitaxel, induces complete response in the majority of patients with carcinoma of the ovary
  • Cisplatin produces responses in cancers of the bladder, head and neck, cervix, and endometrium
  • All forms of carcinoma of the lung; anal and rectal carcinomas; and neoplasms of childhood.
  • The drug also sensitizes cells to radiation therapy and enhances control of locally advanced lung, esophageal, and head and neck tumors when given with irradiation.

Adverse effects:

  • Dose-dependent nephrotoxicity
  • Ototoxicity- high-frequency hearing loss and tinnitus
  • Peripheral motor and sensory neurotoxicity
  • Anemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypophosphatemia
  • AML, usually 4 or more years after treatment

Option B - Streptozotocin use can result in diabetes mellitus due to the destruction of beta cells of the pancreas.

Option C - Methysergide use is associated with retroperitoneal fibrosis.

Option D - Cyclophosphamide causes hemorrhagic cystitis as one of its characteristic side effects.

questions.text: Which among the following is not part of STEP approach by WHO?
questions.solution:
STEP approach doesn't include blood grouping.

STEP approach of WHO is a survey methodology developed to assess risk factors of non-communicable diseases(NCD). It helps the countries to establish an NCD surveillance system. The steps include the following:

  • Questionnaires about behavioral risk factors like tobacco use, alcohol use, diet, and physical activity. 
  • Physical measurements via blood pressure (Option A), height, weight, and waist size
  • Biochemical measurements via blood glucose, blood lipid profile (options C and D ), urinary sodium, and creatinine.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults?
questions.solution:
Malignant melanoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults

Intraocular tumours are tumors affecting the ocular tissue. They are often malignant. They are initially dormant but can cause secondary glaucoma based on the location. It can cause extraocular extension and finally metastasis if left untreated. Types of intraocular tumours:

  • Malignant melanoma: Involves the choroid, ciliary body, or iris. Its start as lens-shaped masses and enlarges. Retinal melanoma can cause retinal detachment. Radiological investigations like CT, MRI, and radioactive tracers, fluorescein angiography are used for diagnosis. Treatment includes surgery, radiation therapy, and enucleation in severe cases
  • Retinoblastoma: Is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children. It presents as a yellow pupillary reflex and cataract. Diagnosis is via demonstration of calcifications in radiographs and CT. Treatment involves brachytherapy and surgery.
  • Reticulum cell sarcoma: It is a primary neoplasm of histiocyte similar to a microglioma in the CNS
  • Secondaries: These mostly arise from the breast and alimentary canal.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl came for a health checkup. She doesn't go to school. Which government program will benefit her?
questions.solution:
Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK), an ambitious initiative, launched under the National Health Mission (NHM) launched envisages early screening and early intervention for children from birth to 18 years. It aims at the universal screening of the 4 ‘D’s, i.e. Defects at birth, Deficiencies, Diseases, Developmental delays, including disabilities, that would lead to early identification, timely management, and ultimately a reduction in morbidity, mortality, and lifelong disability in children.

 Defects:

  • Neural tube defect
  • Down’s syndrome
  • Cleft lip and palate
  • Talipes
  • Developmental dysplasia of the hip
  • Congenital cataract, congenital deafness, congenital heart disease
  • Retinopathy of prematurity

Deficiencies:

  • Anemia, especially severe anemia
  • Vitamin A deficiency
  • Vitamin D deficiency
  • Severe acute malnutrition
  • Goiter

Diseases:

  • Scabies, fungal infections, and eczema
  • Otitis media
  • Rheumatic heart disease
  • Reactive airway disease
  • Dental caries
  • Convulsive disorders

Developmental delays and disabilities:

  • Vision, hearing, and neuromotor impairment
  • Motor, cognitive and language delay
  • Autism
  • Learning disorder
  • Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder

Other options:

Option B: Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) is a program under the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM), whose aim is to reduce maternal mortality by encouraging delivery in government health facilities. Under the scheme, a financial incentive is also provided for giving birth in a government health facility. 

Option C: Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram includes training of doctors, nurses, and ANMs for essential newborn care, early diagnosis, and case management of common ailments of children.

Option D: Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman (PM POSHAN) previously known as Mid-Day Meal Scheme, is a centrally sponsored scheme that provides one hot cooked meal in Government and Government-aided Schools

Under the Scheme, there is a provision of hot cooked meal to all preschool children and also to children of classes I to VIII. The scheme is implemented across the country covering all the eligible children without any discrimination of gender and social class.

questions.text: Name the international agency that aids India in the construction of sanitary latrines.
questions.solution:
Ford Foundation takes part in designing and constructing sanitary latrines in rural areas.

Ford Foundation is assisting more in developing rural health services and family planning. They do this by

  • Setting up orientation centers to train the medical and paramedical personal
  • Projects to solve basic problems in environmental sanitation
  • Projects in rural health services
  • Established National institute of health administration and education
  • Projects to solve water issues in Calcutta
  • Family planning fellowship programs

 Other options

USAID: United States Agency for International Development is one of the three US agencies extending support to India by giving grants and loans. They have been assisting in improving overall health 

CARE: Cooperative for Assistance and Relief everywhere. In India, they primarily take part in providing food to children and now work in conjunction with ICDS for the same

Red Cross: Initially begun to help with war survivors, now it provides help in all sorts of humanitarian crises be it natural or otherwise. In India, they offer healthcare facilities via their hospitals.

questions.text: A patient complains of visual blurring which is relieved on its own. Fundus examination showed papilledema. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Visual blurring in papilledema is called amaurosis fugax

Amaurosis fugax is the transient loss of vision due to an interruption in the blood supply to the retina or brain by emboli or spasms. The onset is abrupt and may follow a falling curtain pattern. The symptoms are relieved upon removal of the insult or the emboli and they recover in the same pattern the vision loss occured.

In papilledema, amaurosis fugax lasts 30-60 seconds. It's usually bilateral but can be unilateral in asymmetric disc edema due to giant cell arteritis or raised intracranial pressure

Other systemic causes can present as amaurosis fugax. Notably, cardiovascular abnormalities like arrhythmias, mitral valve prolapse, venous stasis retinopathies, fibromuscular dysplasia, etc.

Treatment is based on the cause. It's often self-limiting in papilledema. Aspirine or persantine may be used in cases of platelet emboli-induced disease. Severe emboli may require dis-obliteration of the vessels.

Other options:

Option A: Retinal detachment is the separation of retinal epithelium. They may present as visual blurring but is not transient. Fundus examination will show a greyish or whitish tint to the detached portions with evident tears and holes in cases of larger detachments.

Option C: Blindness as per WHO is visual acuity less than 3/60 or corresponding visual field defects in the better eye with the best possible correction. 

Option D: Angle-closure glaucoma presents with painful loss of vision with redness. Fundus examination may show hyperemic disc or maybe even normal disc.

questions.text: 6x6x6 strategy under Anemia Mukt Bharat includes all except:
questions.solution:
Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme implements 6 x 6x 6 strategy which focuses on six target beneficiary groups, through six interventions and six institutional mechanisms to achieve their target by 2022.

The Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme is an initiative that aims to strengthen the existing mechanisms and foster newer strategies for tackling anemia.

Interventions include:

  • Prophylactic iron and folic acid supplementation.
  • Deworming.
  • Intensified year-round Behaviour Change Communication Campaign (Solid Body, Smart Mind) including ensuring delayed cord clamping in newborns.
  • Testing of anemia using digital methods and point-of-care treatment.
  • Mandatory provision of Iron and Folic Acid fortified foods in government-funded health programs.
  • Addressing non-nutritional causes of anemia in endemic pockets, with a special focus on malaria, hemoglobinopathies, and fluorosis.

IFA tablet distribution under Anemia Mukt Bharat:

  • Lactating mothers of 0 to 6-month-old children are given a daily dose of red color IFA tablet containing 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid.
  • Weekly doses of red color IFA tablets containing 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid are given to women of reproductive age (non-pregnant, non-lactating), between 20-49 years of age.
  • Children between 5-9 years of age are given pink color sugar-coated tablets containing 45 mg of elemental iron and 400 mcg of folic acid tablets once a week.
  • Blue color tablets containing 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid can be given to school-going adolescent girls and boys of 10-19 years and out-of-school adolescent girls of age 10-19 years.

questions.text: A child presents to the emergency department with lethargy. On examination, the child is unresponsive, unable to take oral feeds, eyes dry and sunken, and severely malnourished. What is the fluid of choice in this child?
questions.solution:
A child with features of severe dehydration like sunken dry eyes, lethargy, and unable to take oral feeds must be started on IV fluid correction for dehydration. Since the child has severe malnutrition as well, the fluid of choice is ringer's lactate with 5% dextrose

The treatment of some dehydration in a child with severe acute malnutrition is half-strength WHO low-osmolarity ORS with glucose and potassium.

ReSoMal is another oral rehydration salt or ORS for severely malnourished children. It is used in in-patient centers for the treatment of children with severe acute malnutrition. ReSoMal contains a higher amount of glucose (125mmol/L) and a lower amount of sodium (45mmol/L) than the standard WHO-ORS.

Full-strength, standard WHO low-osmolarity oral rehydration solution (75 mmol/L of sodium) should not be used for oral or nasogastric rehydration in children with severe acute malnutrition.

Intravenous therapy should be given only for severe dehydration and shock or if the enteral route cannot be used. IV fluids that can be used in these children are

  • Ringer's lactate with 5% dextrose
  • Half-normal saline with 5% dextrose 
  • Half-strength Darrow solution with 5% dextrose.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presented with a fever persisting for 3 weeks. He gives a history of prosthetic valve implantation 6 months before. Investigations reveal mitral valve vegetation and is diagnosed with endocarditis. Which of the following is the most common cause of endocarditis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient who underwent prosthetic valve implantation 6 months back, and currently presents with fever and mitral valve vegetations, most likely has early prosthetic valve endocarditis. The most likely causative organism is coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS) like Staphylococcus epidermidis.

Coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS) is the most common cause of early prosthetic valve endocarditis.

Most common organisms causing endocarditis after implantation of prosthetic valves:

  • <2 months: Coagulase-negative staphylococci > Staphylococcus aureus
  • 2-12 months: Coagulase-negative staphylococci
  • >12 months: Streptococci > Staphylococcus aureus

questions.text: What is the target Maternal mortality rate and Under 5 mortality rate to be achieved by 2030 ?
questions.solution:
The target maternal mortality rate and Under-5 mortality rate to be achieved by 2030 are 70 and 25, respectively.

SDG(Sustainable development goals) comprises of 17 goals and 170 targets for Agenda 2030.

The SDGs adopted in 2015 aim to reduce Under-5 mortality to as low as 25 per 1000 live births by the year 2030.

The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), also known as the Global Goals, were adopted by the United Nations in 2015 as a call to action to end poverty, protect the planet, and ensure that by 2030 all people enjoy peace and prosperity.

It consists of 17 integrated sustainable development goals to be achieved by the year 2030, with priority being given to countries that are farthest behind. The SDGs are designed to end poverty, hunger, AIDS, and discrimination against women and girls.

SDG 3 deals with ensuring healthy lives and promoting well-being for all at all ages. The important sub-targets of SDG 3 are:

Sub-target Goal
3.1 Reduce global maternal mortality to <70/100,000 live births.
3.2
  • Reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12/1000 live births.
  • Reduce under 5 mortality to at least as low as 25/1000 live births.
3.3 End epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria, and neglected tropical diseases, combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases, and other communicable diseases
3.5 Prevention and treatment of substance abuse, narcotic abuse, and harmful use of alcohol.
3.7 Universal access to sexual and reproductive health care services, including family planning.
3.9 Substantially reduce deaths and illnesses due to hazardous chemicals and air, water, and soil pollution and contamination.

 Given below is an overview of the 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)

questions.text: A patient tested positive for HBsAg, HBeAg and IgM Anti HBc. What is the status of the condition the patient is affected by?

choices.text: HBV infection in the recent past

questions.solution:
Positive HBsAg, and HBeAg with positive IgM anti-HBc antibodies correspond to acute hepatitis (early-phase, high infectivity)

HbsAg is positive only when the patient has an acute infection or a chronic carrier. Anti HBc antibody appear during acute infection and persists

Other Options:

Option B: Chronic hepatitis B with active viral replication has the following serological findings: HBsAg positive, Anti-HBc IgG positive, HBeAg positive, and Anti-HBe negative.

Option C: HBV infection in the recent past- Anti-HBs positive and Anti-HBc IgG positive

Option D: Post-vaccination- only Anti-HBs positive

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

questions.text: Recommended daily protein intake (high quality) for an adult male weighing 55 kg is
questions.solution:
The recommended protein intake in terms of a high-quality protein diet for adult men and women as given by the FAO/WHO 2007 and ICMR 2020 guidelines is 0.83g/kg/d. So for a male weighing 55kg, the protein requirement is 55x0.83 g per day, about 46 g.

Dietary Reference Intakes

  • Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) - The average daily dietary intake that is sufficient to meet the requirements of almost all individuals in a group

The EAR for an elderly male (>60 years) is 1700 Kcal/D and for an elderly female (>60 years) is 1500 Kcal/D.

Note: There is no RDA for energy. The EAR is equivalent to Estimated Energy Requirement (EER).

questions.text: Which among the following are the yoke muscles of levodepression?

choices.text: Right superior oblique (SO) and left inferior rectus (IR)
Right  superior oblique (SO) and left  inferior oblique (IO)
Right medial rectus (MR) and left medial rectus (MR)
Right medial rectus (MR) and right lateral rectus (LR)

questions.solution:
Right superior oblique (SO) and left inferior rectus (IR) are the yoke muscle pair for levodepression.

The term "yoke muscles" refers to contralateral synergists.

  • Includes a pair of muscles, one from each eye, which contract simultaneously during version movements.
  • Examples are 
    • Right MR and Left LR for levoversion
    • Right LR and Left MR for dextroversion

In an outward deviated eye, the elevation and depression is by recti. So here, one of the muscles is left inferior rectus. 

Easy method to determine other muscle yoke muscle pairs:

Just take the opposite of each word:

Left  → Right

Inferior → Superior

Rectus → Oblique

So right superior rectus is the pair.

Similarly, the following are yoke muscle pairs:

  • Right IO and Left SR - Levoelevation
  • Right SR and Left IO - Dextroelevation
  • Right IR and Left SO - Dextrodepression

questions.text: In the pediatric wards, you notice a baby completely preoccupied with play and a mother trying hard to spoonfeed him. He is busy stacking toy cubes on top of each other and starts gleefully clapping once he makes a tower of 6 cubes. What is the likely age that this milestone corresponds to?
questions.solution:
A child can usually make a tower of 6 blocks by 24 months.

A child makes a tower of

  • 2 blocks by 15 months
  • 3 blocks by 18 months
  • 6 blocks by 2 years
  • 9 blocks by 3 years.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a crush injury on his hand. He says that he received his last dose of TT vaccination at the age of 23. What is the treatment of choice in this patient?

choices.text: Wound care with single dose tetanus toxoid
Wound care with full course of TT vaccine
Wound care with tetanus Ig and TT vaccine

questions.solution:
Wound care with a single dose of tetanus toxoid is given as the patient is category B, with the last dose received more than 5 years ago but less than 10 years.

Related Pearl: Post exposure prophylaxis for tetanus

Prophylaxis is given based on patient category:

  1. Full immunization or a booster dose within the past 5 years.
  2. Full immunization or a booster dose > 5 years ago but < 10 years.
  3. Full immunization or a booster dose > 10 years ago.
  4. Unknown or never taken immunization
Category Clean wound Unclean wound
A Only wound care Only wound care
B Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose
C Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose + Human tetanus immunoglobulin 
D Wound care + TT complete course Wound care + TT complete course + Human tetanus immunoglobulin

questions.text: A patient presents with hypertension,palpitations and sweating. His catecholamine and aldosterone levels were found to be elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of hypertension, sweating and palpitation with elevated catecholamine levels point towards pheochromocytoma.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of Pheochromocytoma (By frequency of occurrence)

  • Clinical triad:
    • Headaches – M/C symptom
    • Profuse sweating
    • Palpitations and tachycardia
  • Hypertension, sustained or paroxysmal – M/C Sign
  • Anxiety and panic attacks
  • Weight loss
  • Polyuria and polydipsia
  • Constipation
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy
  • Erythrocytosis
  • Elevated blood sugar
  • Hypercalcemia

Related Pearl: Pheochromocytoma

Features:

  • When pheochromocytoma is associated with the MEN syndrome it is rarely malignant.
  • Phaeochromocytomas are greyish-pink on the cut surface and are usually highly vascularised.
  • Zellbalen cells and nuclei with salt and pepper chromatin are seen.

Factors indicating more chances of malignancy:

  • An increased PASS (phaeochromocytoma of the adrenal gland scale score)
  • High number of Ki-67-positive cells
  • Vascular invasion or a breached capsule

Diagnosis:

  • Urinary catecholamine and VMA level assay are most sensitive screening test.
  • MRI is the IOC.
  • Biopsy and CT Contrast scan are contraindicated in order to avoid Hypertensive crisis.

Treatment:

  • Adrenalectomy is preferred TOC.
  • Size<5 cm -  Laparoscopic adrenalectomy
  • Preop Alpha blockers should be given
  • Mitotane should be started as adjuvant or palliative treatment
