questions.text: A 42-year-old woman undergoes hip arthroplasty. The consultant advises starting the patient on dabigatran to prevent venous thromboembolism. How does this drug prevent thrombosis in this patient?

choices.text: Inhibition of  vitamin K epoxide reductase

questions.solution:
Dabigatran prevents venous thromboembolism by direct thrombin inhibition.

Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor (DTI). It belongs to a new class of anticoagulant drugs that prevent thrombin from cleaving fibrinogen to fibrin. Parenteral DTIs include bivalirudin, argatroban, and desirudin. The only oral DTI available for clinical use is dabigatran.

They are used in:

  • Prevention of embolic stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation (without valvular heart disease)
  • Venous thromboembolic disease (VTE)
  • Postoperative thromboprophylaxis in patients undergoing hip and knee arthroplasty

The major adverse effect of dabigatran is bleeding. There is an additional risk for bleeding in renal impairment and concurrent use of antiplatelet agents or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. Dabigatran is contraindicated for stroke prevention in patients with mechanical heart valves.

Other options:

Option A: Heparin acts by activating antithrombin III, thereby inactivating the active form of clotting factors II, IX, X, XI, XII, and XIII. Adverse effects are bleeding and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) due to the formation of antibodies against the heparin-platelet complex.

Option C: Warfarin is an anticoagulant that inhibits the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase. It catalyzes the conversion of oxidized vitamin K to the reduced form of vitamin K. The reduced vitamin K is involved in the carboxylation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, X, and proteins C and S.

Options D: Rivaroxaban and apixaban are direct oral factor Xa inhibitors that inhibit the free and clot-associated factor Xa resulting in reduced thrombin generation.

questions.text: An industrial worker was admitted to the hospital with complaints of visual disturbances. On examination, there is iron deposits in his eye. What is the most likely diagnosis behind this occular finding?
questions.solution:
The presence of iron deposits in the eye especially in industrial workers is called siderosis bulbi.

Siderosis bulbi refers to the ocular degenerative changes produced by an iron foreign body. It usually occurs 2 months to 2 years after the injury. This condition is due to the electrolytic dissociation of the metal by an intrinsic resting current in the eye which disseminates the metal, combining it with cellular proteins and causing atrophy.

Clinical features:

  • Iris: First stained greenish and later turned reddish-brown, causing heterochromia iridis.
  • Pupil: iron deposition in the sphincter leads to mydriasis.
  • Lens: iron deposition in a radial fashion on the anterior capsule of the lens, leading to anterior capsular cataract.
  • Retina: pigmentary retinopathy; followed by atrophy of the retina and retinal pigmentary epithelium.
  • Secondary open-angle Glaucoma: due to damage to the trabecular meshwork.

Kayser-Fleischer ring refers to the golden brown arc along the limbus seen at the level of descemets membrane in copper metabolism disorder Wilson

Chalcosis refers to the electrolytic dissociation of copper particles and its deposition in the eye forming a brown coloured ring similar to the KF ring in Wilson's disease

Retinitis pigmentosa refers to the degenrative disease of the retinal pigmental epithelium. It presents with scotomas and otherwise normal on general and slit lamb examination

questions.text: A 7-year-old child has a grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur along the left sternal border. S2 is widely split and does not vary with respiration. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child presents typically with fixed wide split S2, a classic finding of the atrial septal defect (ASD), a type of acyanotic congenital heart disease.

ASDs are abnormal, fixed openings in the atrial septum caused by incomplete tissue formation that allows communication of blood between the left and right atria. The ASD creates a left-to-right shunt that increases the blood flow to the right side of the heart. This causes the pulmonary valve to close later than the aortic valve independent of inspiration/expiration. This leads to a fixed wide split S2.

Most ASDs are asymptomatic and are picked up during routine physical examinations.

A mild left precordial bulge and a right ventricular systolic lift may be palpable at the left sternal border. Sometimes, a pulmonic ejection click can be heard. Echocardiography will show characteristic right ventricular volume overload, including an increased right ventricular end-diastolic dimension and flattening and abnormal motion of the ventricular septum.

Other options:

Option A: Ventricular septal defect (VSD) is typically associated with a pan-systolic murmur best heard in the left lower sternal border.

Option C: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is typically associated with a harsh systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border (pulmonic area) with a single 2nd heart sound (S2)

Option D: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is characteristically associated with a machinery murmur.

questions.text: Which of the following forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle?
questions.solution:
The lateral boundary of the femoral triangle is formed by the medial margin of the sartorius.

Its medial boundary is formed by the medial margin of adductor longus.

Related Pearl: Femoral Triangle

The femoral triangle is a depressed, intermuscular space present in the anteromedial aspect of the proximal thigh.

Boundaries of Femoral triangle are:

Medially- Medial border of Adductor longus

Laterally- Medial border of Sartorius

Base- Inguinal ligament

Floor (lateral to medial)- Iliacus, Psoas major, Pectineus, Adductor longus

Roof- Skin, Superficial fascia, Fascia lata, superficial branches of femoral vessels–superficial epigastric, superficial external pudendal, superficial circumflex iliac vessels and GSV. 

Note: Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve which forms a content of the triangle also forms its roof as it pierces the fascia to supply the skin over the triangle. 

Contents:

  • Femoral sheath containing lymph node of Cloquet, femoral vein, femoral artery, femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve.
  • Femoral nerve and its branches
  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve of thigh

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with hemoptysis, blood-coloured nasal discharge. On examination, there is septal perforation. Biopsy from the nose shows necrosis and non-caseating granuloma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing septal perforation, bloody nasal discharge with non caseating granuloma is suggestive of Wegener's granulomatosis (granulomatosis with polyangiitis).

Wegener's granulomatosis is a systemic disorder which primarily involve the upper airways, lungs, kidneys, and the skin

Involvement of the upper respiratory tract in granulomatosis with polyangiitis manifests as:

  • Paranasal sinusitis, serous otitis media
  • Nasal ulcers, purulent or bloody nasal discharge
  • Nasal perforation leading to the destruction of septum and saddle nose deformity
  • Subglottic tracheal stenosis

General symptoms like fatigue night sweats, and arthralgia is also seen. Once lung involvement happens, cough and hemoptysis begins. Renal involvement is late and is detected as RBC and casts in urine.

Diagnosis is primarily by nasal biopsy which will show necrosis and non-caseating granuloma. X-ray chest will show cavitations in case of lung involvement.

Management consists of systemic steroids, cyclophosphamide and azathioprine

Other options:

Option A: Tuberculosis presents with generalised symptoms but is accompanies by a caseating granuloma

Option B: Leprosy can present as a deformity on the nose and nasal perforation but is often accompanied by crusting. It is also accompanied by skin symptoms like anaesthesia and nerve involvement

Option C: Sarcoidosis presents as nodules on the septum and epistaxis but presents without caseation

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presented with recurrent URTI, poor growth, high-arched palate, and impaired hearing. Tympanogram is given as follows. What would be the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with type B tympanometry curve is suggestive of serous otitis media secondary to adenoid hypertrophy. Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion would be the most appropriate management.

Enlarged adenoids in children can present as nasal obstruction, rhinolalia clausa, recurrent acute otitis media, and serous otitis media. Adenoid facies, characterized by an elongated face, open mouth, teeth crowding, high arched hard palate, and pinched-in nose, may also be present.

Serous otitis media also known as secretory otitis media, mucoid otitis media, or glue ear is characterized by the accumulation of nonpurulent, serous effusion in the middle ear cleft. 

Glue ear can occur either due to eustachian tube dysfunction (adenoid hyperplasia, chronic sinusitis or tonsillitis or rhinitis, cleft palate, tumors of nasopharynx) or due to increased secretory activity of the middle ear mucosa (allergy, unresolved otitis media, viral infections).

Glue ear is commonly seen in children aged 5-8 years and is associated with insidious onset of hearing loss (not exceeding 40 dB), mild ear aches, and a history of upper respiratory tract infections. Delayed or defective speech may also result from hearing loss.

Otoscopy shows: 

  • Dull and opaque tympanic membrane with loss of light reflex
  • Thin leash of vessels along the handle of the malleus 
  • Fluid levels and air bubbles can be seen when the tympanic membrane is transparent. 

The otoscopy image of serous otitis media is shown below:

The tuning fork test reveals a conductive type of hearing loss and audiometry reveals hearing loss in the range of 20–40 dB. The fluid accumulation in glue ear causes decreased mobility (compliance) of the tympanic membrane leading to a flat or dome-shaped curve or type B curve on a tympanogram.

Treatment is mainly aimed at the removal of fluid and preventing recurrence. 

  • Medical management includes decongestants, antihistamines, and antibiotics.
  • Surgical management is done if the condition cannot be controlled with medications. It includes myringotomy and aspiration of fluid with grommet insertion. Adenoidectomy and tonsillectomy may be required and are usually done at the time of myringotomy.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: Bulla ethmoidalis drains into which among the following?
questions.solution:
Bulla ethmoidalis -It is an ethmoidal cell situated behind the uncinate process.
It forms posterior boundary of hiatus semilunaris  and drains to middle meatus

Related Pearl: Structures opening into meatuses of nose

  • Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner
  • Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.
  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text: A patient developed hypotension, bradycardia and apnea on injection of an irritant substance. Which of the following physiological reflexes is involved in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The circulatory collapse, apnea in a patient following injection of irritant is due to Bezold-Jarisch Reflex. 

It is the activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibres in the cardiopulmonary region (e.g. juxta capillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery) that causes profound brady­cardia, hypotension and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing 

It can be elicited by :

  • Substances like capsaicin, serotonin, phenyl biguanide, veratridine
  • Myocardial ischemia and reperfusion as a result of increased production of oxygen radicals 
  • Radiocontrast agents for coronary angiography

Other options:

Option A: Tachycardia following acute volume overload is due to the Bainbridge Reflex. The stretch receptors of the atria that elicit the Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. Efferent signals are then transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase heart rate and strength of heart contraction.

Option B: Hypertension following a head injury is due to the Cushing Reflex. When the intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to RVLM neurons is compromised. The local hypoxia and hypercapnia cause an increase in discharge from the neurons, producing hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration. The resultant rise in systemic arterial pressure tends to restore the blood flow to the medulla.

questions.text: A neonate was brought with yellow sclera and hypoglycemia. He is exclusively breastfed. Urine Benedict's test is positive. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient in this neonate?
questions.solution:
Features of jaundice and hypoglycemia in a neonate who is breastfed, suggest a diagnosis of Classic Galactosemia, in which there is a deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase.

Classic galactosemia:

  • Deficiency of galactose-1-uridyltransferase leads to the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate and galactitol
  • Infants show vomiting, diarrhea, and poor weight gain within 3-4 days of breastfeeding
  • Jaundice and liver dysfunction appear in the first or second week of life. 
  • Proximal renal tubular disease may also manifest as metabolic acidosis, galactosuria, glucosuria, and aminoaciduria
  • Most common cause of death is E.coli sepsis
  • Acute galactose toxicity is manifested by neurological symptoms
  • Diagnosis is made by genetic or mutational analysis. There will be presence of reducing substances in the urine.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presents to the OPD with complaints of fatigue. On examination, there is pallor. Blood investigations showed a hemoglobin of 10g/dl, RBC count of  3 million cells/mm cube, MCV = 70 fL, MCH = 22 pg.  What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical findings are consistent iron deficiency anemia 

This patient has microcytic (N: 82-96 fL) and hypochromic (N: 27-33 pg) anemia. The differential diagnoses of microcytic hypochromic anemia include iron deficiency, thalassemia, sideroblastic anemia, and anemia of chronic disease. Since there is reduced RBC count (normal 4.5 to 6.5 milllion/cubic mm), the best answer is Iron deficiency anemia.

The single best test to differentiate between various diagnosis of microcytic hypochromic anemia is iron profile.  Low Ferritin and high TIBC( total iron binding capacity) is seen in Iron deficiency anaemia, while Thalassemia major has normal/high ferritin and low/normal TIBC.

Related Pearl: Differential Diagnosis of Microcytic Anaemia

Investigation Iron- Deficiency Anemia Thalassemia Minor Anemia of Chronic Disease
Serum Iron <50 µg/dL Normal/Increased Decreased
Serum Ferritin <30 µg/L Normal/Increased Increased
TIBC Increased Normal Decreased
Transferrin saturation <15% Normal Normal/Decreased
Transferrin Receptor-Ferritin Index High (>2) Normal Low (<2)
MCV Decreased Markedly Decreased May be low or normal
RBC count <5 million/µL >5 million/µL Normal
Mentzer Index ≥13 <13 N/A
RDW-CV(%) >15 <15 Normal/Increased

TIBC: Total iron-binding capacity

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of irreversible injury?
questions.solution:
Blebbing of plasma membrane is a feature of reversible injury

Within limits, a cell can repair derangements and, if the injurious stimulus abates, will return to normalcy. This is called reversible cell injury. Persistent or excessive injury, however, causes cells to pass the rather nebulous “point of no return” into irreversible injury and cell death.

The ultrastructural changes of reversible cell injury include:

  • Plasma membrane alterations, such as blebbing, blunting, and loss of microvilli
  • Mitochondria - swelling and the appearance of small amorphous densities
  • Dilation of the ER, with the detachment of polysomes
  • Intracytoplasmic myelin figures
  • Nuclear alterations- disaggregation of granular and fibrillar elements

Irreversible cell injury

  • Increased eosinophilia, glassy homogeneous appearance
  • Whorled phospholipid masses called myelin figures derived from damaged cell membranes
  • Discontinuities in plasma and organelle membranes
  • Marked dilation of mitochondria with the appearance of large amorphous densities
  • Intracytoplsmic amorphous debris, and aggregates of fluffy material probably representing denatured protein.
  • Nuclear changes- karyolysis, pyknosis and karyorrhexis

questions.text: A hypertensive patient comes to the OPD with complaints of visual disturbances. On fundoscopy, multiple flame-shaped hemorrhages , cotton wool spots, and disc edema were found. What is the grade of hypertensive retinopathy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Cotton wool spots and flame shaped hemorrage with disc edema is seen in grade IV of hypertensive retinopathy. 

Grading of hypertensive retinopathy:

  • Grade 1: Mild generalized retinal arteriolar narrowing 
  • Grade 2: Focal arteriolar narrowing and arteriovenous nipping.
  • Grade 3: Grade 2 plus retinal hemorrhages (dot, blot, flame) or exudates (chronic retinal edema may result in the deposition of hard exudates around the fovea as a ‘macular star’ and cotton wool spots; may also be associated with banking of veins distal to arteriovenous crossings (Bonnet sign), tapering of veins on either side of the crossings (Gunn sign); copper-wire appearance; more prominent arteriovenous compression.
  • Grade 4: Severe grade 3 plus optic disc swelling (a marker of malignant hypertension) and silver-wiring of arterioles.

questions.text: A male patient presents with hydrophobia, tearing, and altered sensorium after a dog bite. You suspect rabies in this patient and take corneal scrapings to confirm the same. What test is performed to obtain the most accurate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Detection of rabies virus RNA by RT-PCR(reverse transcriptase -polymerase chain reaction) on corneal scrapings is highly sensitive and specific.

This technique can detect viruses in fresh saliva samples, CSF, skin, and brain tissues. RT-PCR with genetic sequencing can distinguish among rabies variants, permitting identification of the probable source of an infection.

Clinical stages of rabies:

PHASE TYPICAL DURATION SYMPTOMS AND SIGNS
Incubation period 20-90 Days None
Prodrome 2-10 days Fever, malaise, nausea, vomiting, paresthesia
Acute neurologic disease    
Encephalitic/Furious rabies (80%) 2-7 days Anxiety, Agitation, Hyperactivity, hallucinations, hydrophobia, autonomic dysfunction
Paralytic /dumb rabies (20%) 2-10 days Flaccid paralysis in limbs progressing to quadriparesis with facial paralysis.
Coma, death 0-14 days  (14 Days of encephalitic rabies and 30 days of paralytic rabies)

 Laboratory diagnosis of rabies is performed by the following methods:

  • Antigen detection - Direct immunofluorescence (IF) from specimens of
    • Skin biopsy from the nape of the neck including hair follicles. Rabies antigen is present in cutaneous nerves at the base of hair follicles. It is the most sensitive and specific test.
    • Corneal smears were previously used. They are not used anymore as they are of low diagnostic yield.
  • Viral isolation- Intracerebral inoculation in mice can be attempted from the brain, CSF, and saliva
  • Antibody demonstration from serum and CSF
  • Viral RNA detection by RT-PCR 
  • Postmortem examination of brain tissue samples- demonstration of Negri bodies

Post-exposure, measures like washing the affected area with plenty of soap and water under a running tap for 15 minutes, irrigation of the wound with alcohol or povidone-iodine, local antibiotics and tetanus toxoid should be given.

Different wound categories for post-exposure prophylaxis:

Categories of wound Post-exposure prophylaxis
Category I - touching or feeding animals, licks on intact skin None
Category II - nibbling of uncovered skin, minor scratches, or abrasions
without bleeding		 Immediate vaccination and
local treatment of the wound
Category III- single or multiple transdermal bites or scratches, licks on broken skin contacts with bats Immediate vaccination and
administration of rabies
immunoglobulin; local
treatment of the wound

Post-exposure prophylaxis regimen for rabies:

  • Intramuscular regimen: In this regimen, 1 ml or 0.5 ml of vaccine is injected into the deltoid in patients with category II and III wounds.
    • Essen regimen: It is a 5-dose regimen in which 1 dose of vaccine is given on days 0, 3, 7, 14, and 28 each.
    • Zagreb regimen: It is a 4-dose multisite regimen in which 2 doses of vaccine are given on day 0, followed by 1 dose days 7 and 21 each.
  • Intradermal regimen: In this regimen, 0.1 ml of injection is given at 2 sites on days 0, 3, 7, and 28 each.

Other lab Diagnosis:

  • Once rabies is suspected, rabies-specific laboratory tests should be performed to confirm the diagnosis.
  • Diagnostic specimens: Serum, CSF, fresh saliva, and skin biopsy samples from neck and brain tissue.
  • Antibody detection- Rabies virus- specific antibodies in CSF is more significant than serum antibodies as serum antibodies appear late and can also be present after vaccination.
  • Rabies antigen detection-Direct fluorescent antibody testing with rabies virus antibodies conjugated to fluorescent dyes is highly sensitive and specific and can be performed quickly  and applied to skin biopsies and brain tissue.In skin biopsies ,rabies virus antigen may be detected  in cutaneous nerves at base of hair follicles.
  • Negri body detection - pathognomic for post mortem diagnosis of rabies.May not be detected in 20% of cases.Most common sites are neurons of cerebellum and hippocampus.

questions.text: What is the condition shown in this picture?
questions.solution:
The image shows Popeye sign and it is seen in rupture of proximal tendon of biceps.  Proximal tendon of biceps refers to both long head and short head of biceps.

Popeye sign: On flexing the elbow there is an extremely prominent bulge of the muscle belly as its unrestrained fibers contract.

The proximal biceps tendon makes up 90-97% of all biceps tendon ruptures. In isolation, it has little effect on the upper limb function 

The 4 most common areas of tendon rupture include:

  • Quadriceps
  • Achilles
  • Rotator cuff (most commonly, the supraspinatus)
  • Biceps.

questions.text: Which of the following layers is absent in esophagus?
questions.solution:
The serosa is absent in the esophagus except in the intra-abdominal part.

The oesophagus consists of the following layers:

  • Mucosa:Inner-most layer is the mucous membrane with the following sub-layers:
    • Lining epithelium: non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium
    • Lamina propria: connective tissue supporting the lining epithelium
    • Muscularis mucosae: thin layer of smooth muscle
  •  Submucosa: A special feature of the submucosa is the presence of compound tubuloalveolar mucous glands
  •  Muscularis externa with the inner layer of circular muscle fibres and an outer layer of longitudinal muscle fibres
    • Upper 1/3rd: Only skeletal muscle fibres are present
    • Middle 1/3rd: Both skeletal and smooth muscle fibres are present
    • Lower 1/3rd: Only smooth muscle fibres are present
The stomach has 3 layers in the muscularis externa, with an extra oblique layer. 
In the colon, the outer longitudinal fibers join to form prominent bundles called the taenia coli.
  • Adventitia: Most of the esophagus has a dense fibrous tissue covering called the adventitia. Only a short length of the esophagus in the lower part(Intra-abdominal) has a peritoneal covering (serosa).

questions.text: A patient sustained an injury to the head and now presents with blood collected around his eyes. Attachment of which of the following structure leads to this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of blood collection around eye is called black eye or raccoon eye. It occurs due to the extravasation of blood to periorbital connective tissue. The attachment of aponeurosis in such a manner that the sub-aponeurotic tissue is continuous with the periorbital connective tissue.

The scalp is a soft tissue that covers the calvaria of the skull. It consists of five layers (Mnemonic- SCALP):

  1. Skin
  2. Connective tissue (superficial fascia) with blood vessels and nerves
  3. Aponeurosis (galea aponeurotica) with occipitofrontalis muscle
  4. Loose areolar (sub-aponeurotic) tissue
  5. Pericranium

The sub-aponeurotic tissue loose areolar tissue of the scalp is referred to as the dangerous area of the scalp. Infection from this layer can pass into the cranial cavity through small emissary veins, which pass through parietal foramina in the calvaria. It can reach intracranial structures causing meningitis and intracranial abscesses. It is also continuous with submuscular connective tissue of the eyelid. Hence pus or effusions that can occur at the scalp can drain down to this level

questions.text: Which among the following is a mediator of chronic inflammation?
questions.solution:
TGF beta is a chronic inflammatory mediator.

Macrophages are the chief cells of chronic inflammation. The mediators secreted by activated macrophage is primal for the elimination of the trigger of inflammation but also for the deleterious effect on the body. There are 2 major pathways for macrophage activation.

  • The classical pathway: triggered by the microbial products and mediated by T cell derived signals like IFN gamma. Activated macrophages will secrete NO and lysosomal enzymes to kill the microbe and promote the initial phase of inflammation
  • The alternate pathway: Activated by other t-cell cytokines like IL 4, IL 13. They promote tissue fibrosis and repair via mediators like TGF beta

T cells too play an important role in chronic inflammation. CD4 T cells secrete cytokines and promote the inflammation.

  • Th1 secrete cytokine IFN γ to activate macrophages
  • Th2 secrete IL 4, IL 5, IL 13 for recruiting eosinophils.
  • Th16 along with Th1 involved in response against microbes and in autoimmune diseases

T cells and macrophages act in a bidirectional way, activating each other and continuing the cycle of damage and repair.

The cytokines TNF, IL-1, and IL-6 are important mediators of the acute-phase reaction.

questions.text: Which of the following minerals help with stabilization of insulin secretion?
questions.solution:
Among the options provided, Zinc is best known for its role in the stabilization of insulin secretion.

Zinc is an essential trace element that plays a crucial role in various physiological processes, including insulin metabolism and secretion.

It is involved in the synthesis, storage, and secretion of insulin by pancreatic beta cells. Zinc acts as a cofactor for enzymes involved in insulin processing and storage within the beta cells.

Deficiency of zinc can lead to impaired insulin synthesis and secretion, which may contribute to metabolic disturbances seen in conditions like diabetes.

Other options:

  • Copper is involved in the formation of enzymes called cuproenzymes, including ceruloplasmin, which plays a role in iron metabolism and antioxidant defense.
  • Cadmium is a toxic heavy metal and is not known to have any beneficial role in the body, including insulin regulation. 
  • Iron is crucial for the formation of hemoglobin, which is responsible for transporting oxygen in the blood. It plays a role in overall metabolic processes and energy production within the body. Excess iron levels in the body can be harmful and are associated with various health conditions, including insulin resistance.

questions.text: Which is the drug of choice for refractive testing in a child with squint?
questions.solution:
1% atropine is the drug of choice in refractive testing in a child with a squint. 

The most common cause of squint in children is due to ciliary spasm. Hence proper evaluation is required for refractive testing with cycloplegia as well. Atropine is used because of its high cycloplegic capacity and useful in children who inherently have high ciliary tone

Option B: Tropicamide is short-acting and the maximum effect lasts just 30 mins. Hence not preferred

Option C: Homatropine is less potent

Option D: Cyclopentolate has a shorter duration of action and has less cycloplegic effect. Hence not preferred

questions.text: Which of the following carcinomas is least likely to be seen in a patient on oral contraceptives?
questions.solution:
Oral contraceptive pills (OCP) protect against endometrial carcinomas. This effect is thought to be due to the opposition of estrogen induces proliferation by progestins in OCP. They also decrease the incidence of ovarian and colorectal cancers.

Other benefits of oral contraceptive pills:

  • Regularisation of menstrual cycles results in relief of dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia
  • Reduced incidence of fibrocystic breast disease and ovarian cysts
  • Endometriosis and pelvic inflammatory disease are improved

On the other hand, OCP increase the incidence of hepatic adenomas , HCC and breast cancers.

questions.text: A female presented with a history of profuse vaginal discharge. Microscopy revealed the cell shown in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a clue cell - an epithelial cell with a fuzzy border due to adherence of bacteria. This along with the given clinical features suggests bacterial vaginosis. 

Bacterial vaginosis is a polymicrobial infection caused by Mobiluncus curtisii, Gardnerella vaginalis, Mycoplasma hominis, and Haemophilus vaginalis. It has a malodorous (fishy smell) vaginal discharge with minimal vulval irritation.

Amsel's Criteria is helpful in diagnosing bacterial vaginosis when 3 of the following 4 are present

  • Thin, white homogenous vaginal discharge
  • A pH of vaginal fluid >4.5
  • Fishy odor of discharge accentuated by adding 10% KOH-Whiff test
  • Presence of Clue cells on microscopy. 

Treatment is oral metronidazole 500 mg BD for 7 days. Alternatively, Ampicillin 500 mg or cephalosporin 500 mg

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

  Bacterial vaginosis Trichomonas vaginitis

Candidal vaginitis
Causative organism  Altered vaginal flora- increased concentration of Gardnerella vaginalis Trichomonas vaginalis Candida albicans
Aetiology Increased vaginal pH Sexually transmitted Decreased immunity
Sexual transmission No Yes No
Discharge Fishy, thin, yellow Frothy, green Curdy, white
Symptoms Fishy odour, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning
pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5
Speculum No vaginal epithelium inflammation Strawberry cervix Inflamed-epithelium
KOH Positive Whiff test The whiff test can be positive. Pseudohyphae seen.
Wet mount Clue cells. No WBCs seen Motile trichomaonads, WBCs seen WBCs seen
Treatment Metronidazole or Clindamycin Metronidazole, treat partner also Oral or vaginal azole, no need to treat partner.

questions.text: Type 2 lepra reaction is caused by __________.
questions.solution:
Erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL) or type 2 lepra reaction is caused by type III hypersensitivity reaction which is immune-complex mediated.

Type 2 lepra reactions (ENL) are mainly seen in multibacillary disease; LL(50%)>BL(15%). They can occur before, during, or after treatment, and are commonly recurrent. These reactions are caused by immune complexes (type 3 hypersensitivity).
ENL presents with painful, erythematous nodules on the face and extensor surfaces of limbs. Systemic manifestations like fever, malaise, anorexia, neuritis, uveitis, dactylitis, arthritis, myositis, etc. can also be seen.

Treatment of type 2 lepra reactions includes high-dose steroids, thalidomide (drug of choice in young men with severe ENL), and clofazimine.

Type 1 lepra reaction, on the other hand, is caused by type IV hypersensitivity reaction i.e. cell-mediated immune inflammation within existing skin lesions.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs restrict the availability of thymidylate?
questions.solution:
5-FU acts during the S phase of the cell cycle inhibiting DNA synthesis by restricting the availability of thymidylate

5-FU acts via two different pathways depending on its dose: G1- S-phase cell cycle arrest and apoptosis at a higher dose and G2-M-phase cell cycle arrest at a low dose.

5-FU:

  • Converted in the body to the corresponding nucleotide 5-deoxyuridine monophosphate, which forms a covalent ternary complex with methyl-THFA and thymidylate synthase, resulting in the irreversible inhibition of thymidylate synthase.
  • Failure of DNA synthesis occurs due to the non-availability of thymidylate.
  • Inhibition of TS by 5-FU depends on THFA, infusion of leucovorin will enhance the efficacy of this drug. Cisplatin and oxaliplatin also synergize with this drug.
  • Rapidly dividing cells are most commonly affected, but resting cells are also affected.
  • Used as an anticancer drug for many solid cancers such as the colon, rectum, stomach, pancreas, liver, urinary bladder, head, and neck. Topical preparations are used in BCC and actinic keratosis.
  • Toxicity includes myelosuppression, mucositis, diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting. Peripheral neuropathy may also occur.

Note:

Monoclonal antibodies recognize the extracellular domain of the EGFR, inhibit ligand-induced signaling, and can elicit an immune response. Cetuximab is a recombinant, chimeric human/mouse IgG1 antibody that binds to EGFR and prevents ligand-dependent signaling and receptor dimerization, thereby blocking cell growth and survival signals. It is used to treat patients with metastatic colon cancers and Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma(HNSCC)

Other options:

Option A: Rituximab is an anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody and is used in the treatment of lymhomas.

Option B: Cisplatin induces its cytotoxic properties through binding to nuclear DNA and subsequent interference with normal transcription, and/or DNA replication mechanisms.

Option D: Methotrexate inhibits purine and pyrimidine synthesis, which accounts for its efficacy in the therapy of cancer as well as for some of its toxicities.  The anticancer activity of methotrexate is by inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR).

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the given histopathology slide.
questions.solution:
The slide shows section of the duodenum and marked structures glands located on the duodenum called Brunner's glands

Brunner's glands (or duodenal glands) are compound tubular submucosal glands present in the upper duodenum (above the sphincter of Oddi).

The alveoli of duodenal glands are lined mostly by mucous secreting columnar cells. Their ducts pass through the muscularis mucosae and empty into the intestinal crypts (of Lieberkuhn). 

The duodenum can be easily differentiated from the jejunum or ileum by the presence of these submucosal glands. The jejunum and ileum do not have glands in their submucosa.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not caused by exotoxins?
questions.solution:
Meningitis is not typically associated with exotoxins.

Meningitis is most commonly caused by bacteria (e.g., Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis) or viruses (e.g., enteroviruses) that directly invade the meninges without relying on exotoxin production.

Other options:

Option B: Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) is associated with the exotoxin produced by the bacterium E. coli O157:H7. The exotoxin responsible for the severe symptoms of HUS is called Shiga toxin.

Option C: Toxic Shock Syndrome (TSS) is associated with exotoxins produced by Staphylococcus aureus, primarily the toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1).

Option D: Pseudomembranous colitis is associated with exotoxins produced by Clostridium difficile, specifically toxins A and B. These toxins are responsible for the characteristic pseudomembranes seen in the colon during this condition.

questions.text: A patient presents with right-sided visual field defects in both eyes while central vision remains unaffected. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Visual field defect involving the right sides of each eye with central vision preserved is called bilateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing. It occurs in lesions of the occipital lobe.

Homonymous hemianopia (HH) involves loss of vision on the same side of the visual field in both eyes. HH is characteristically seen in lesions involving the visual pathway posterior to the optic chiasma.

Lesions involving occipital lobe usually shows macular sparing because macular representation is seperate and quite large as compared to peripheral vision. Moreover, macular area in occipital lobe is supplied both by posterior and middle cerebral artery. In case of vascular lesions (eg stroke) affecting occipital lobe, it is less likely to involve both these arteries.

HH may be either complete or incomplete. 

  • A complete HH is characterised by loss of entire hemifield on the same side in both eyes.
  • An incomplete HH is characterised by partial loss of visual field on the same side in both eyes. Incomplete HH is further classified as congruous or incongruous, depending on whether the extent of partial loss of visual field in both the eyes is same or different, respectively.

Other Options:

Option A: Optic Chiasm Lesion: Bitemporal hemianopia refers to loss of sight in the temporal halves of the visual field, seen in lesions affecting the optic chiasma. 

Option B: Optic Tract Lesion : Lesions at the occipital lobe, optic tract and optic radiation would all cause homonymous hemianopia, but macular sparing will occur in the setting of optic lobe damage.

Option C: Damage to the middle part of the optic chiasm affects fibres crossing at the nasal retina of each eye, leaving the uncrossed fibres from the temporal retinas intact. The resulting loss of vision is confined to the temporal visual field of each eye and this is known as bitemporal hemianopia. It is also called heteronymous hemianopia.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: What does number 9 in the given diagram related to hypertension denote?
questions.solution:
The above diagram depicts the rule of halves, which is observed in hypertension, and "number 9" denotes adequately treated subjects.

The rule of halves depicts that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population of most developed countries were aware of the condition and only half of those aware are being treated and only half of those being treated are considered to be adequately treated. 

The numbers in the diagram denote the following:

  1. Whole community
  2. Normotensive subjects
  3. Hypertensive subjects
  4. Undiagnosed hypertension
  5. Diagnosed hypertension
  6. Diagnosed but untreated
  7. Diagnosed and treated
  8. Inadequately treated
  9. Adequately treated

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with complaints of hematuria, hypertension, and facial puffiness for 3 days. History reveals he had a  throat infection 2 weeks back. Urine examination shows positivity for albumin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of hematuria, hypertension, and facial puffiness with past history of throat infection is suggestive of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). It usually occurs following a throat infection by nephritogenic strains of group A β-hemolytic streptococci. It can also occur after streptococcal skin infection or pyoderma.

 Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis(PSGN) is characterized by the sudden onset of gross hematuria, edema, hypertension, and renal insufficiency. The typical patient develops an acute nephritic syndrome following:
  • 1 to 2 weeks after an antecedent streptococcal pharyngitis or
  • 3 to 6 weeks after streptococcal pyoderma

The pathogenesis involves circulating antibodies elicited by streptococcal antigens reacting with normal glomerular antigens, and complement activation by directly deposited streptococcal antigens cause the immunologic injury.

In this immune complex-mediated APSGN, we see the following in most patients:

  • Decrease in the serum complement (C3) level (levels normalize in 6 to 8 weeks)
  • ASO titer is increased (the titers decrease to low levels within 4 to 6 weeks)
Microscopic Findings in PSGN:
  • Light microscopy: Enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli with diffuse mesangial proliferation and leukocyte infiltration
  • Immunofluorescence: Granular deposits of IgG and complement C3 along the glomerular basement membrane(GBM)and in the mesangium. 
  • Electron microscopy: Electron-dense deposits, or humps, are observed on the epithelial side of the GBM.

Below is the image showing light microscopy findings of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

Group B beta-hemolytic streptococci (Option B) most commonly cause meningitis in neonates. They rarely present with glomerulonephritis

Staph aureus (Option c) causes soft tissue and musculoskeletal infections, infective endocarditis and respiratory infections. Glomerular involvement is rare 

Staph epidermidis (Option d) is responsible for most of the prosthetic device associated infections like endocarditis.

questions.text: A primi presented to the hospital in active labor and was found to be HIV positive. She is not on any antiretroviral therapy. According to the NACO guidelines, what is the minimum prophylactic antiretroviral therapy to be started in the neonate after birth?
questions.solution:
A baby born to an HIV-positive mother who is not on ART is classified as a high-risk infant. The recommended minimum ARV prophylaxis is syrup nevirapine + syrup zidovudine from birth to 6 weeks. For exclusively breastfed infants, this is extended till 12 weeks.

According to the National AIDS Control Organization (NACO), antiretroviral therapy (ART) should be given to all pregnant women, including during labor hours and breastfeeding. They are started on a triple-drug ART. ART should be given irrespective of the CD4 count, and clinical stage and should be continued lifelong.

Exclusive breastfeeding (EBF) is recommended for all HIV-exposed infants. At 6 months of age, these infants should be offered complementary foods along with breast milk.

Infants should receive ARV prophylaxis. A single drug or dual drug regimen is followed depending on the risk of transmission which can be low or high risk.

  • Low-risk infants are those born to mothers with a low viral load which is detected after 32 weeks of pregnancy till delivery. 
  • High-risk infants are those born to HIV-positive mothers, not on ART, with viral load not estimated beyond 32 weeks, maternal viral load not suppressed after 32 weeks, or mothers newly diagnosed with HIV within 6 weeks of delivery.
HIV Risk  ARV prophylaxis Duration
Low-risk infants Syrup nevirapine or zidovudine

 Birth to 6 weeks of age irrespective of feeding 
High-risk infants Syrup nevirapine + syrup zidovudine
  • Exclusive replacement feeding: Birth to 6 weeks
  • Exclusive breastfeeding: Birth till 12 weeks

questions.text: A child presented to the OPD with a characteristic type of cataract as seen in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shown below shows an oil drop cataract seen in galactosemia. Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency leads to classical galactosemia which is an autosomal recessive disorder.

Clinical features :

  • Accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate in the liver causes liver damage & leads to hepatomegaly, vomiting, convulsions.
  • Accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate depletes the liver of inorganic phosphate leading to diminished ATP synthesis which affects gluconeogenesis resulting in hypoglycemia.
  • Accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate in the nerves causes intellectual disability.
  • Accumulation of galactitol in the lens causes oil-drop cataract.
  • Patients with galactosemia are at an increased risk of developing Escherichia coli neonatal sepsis.

Urinary reducing sugar (Benedict's test) and the Mucic acid test is positive.

Treatment is a galactose-free diet.

Diabetes show snow flake cataract, Wilson’s disease shows sunflower cataract and myotonic dystrophy shows Christmas tree cataract.

questions.text: What is the dye used to stain the anterior capsule of the lens in cataract surgery?
questions.solution:
Trypan blue dye can be used to stain the lens capsule for better visibility. It is used in anterior capsulotomy like capsulorrhexis.

In capsulorrhexis, an opening is made in the anterior capsule of the lens. Continuous curvilinear capsulorrhexis (CCC) is considered to be superior to all the pre-existing methods because when done correctly, it does not leave any edges or tears.In ECCE, a portion of the anterior capsule of the lens is removed, allowing extraction of the lens nucleus and cortex. This leaves the remainder of the anterior capsule, the posterior capsule, and the zonular support intact. The intact lens nucleus is then removed from the eye through a limbal incision. 

An anterior capsulotomy is followed by hydrodissection using a balanced salt solution. This helps to separate the corticonuclear mass from the capsule. Removal of lens nucleus and aspiration of the cortex is done using a two-way irrigation and aspiration cannula. An intraocular lens (IOL) is then implanted and the incision is then closed.

questions.text: A patient, a known case of chronic alcoholism is brought to the emergency room with confusion and tremors. On examination, there is ataxia and ophthalmoplegia. Deficiency of which of the following is responsible for the condition?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy. It is seen due to the deficiency of thiamine/vitamin B1.

Wernicke's encephalopathy/alcoholic encephalopathy is an acute neurological disorder. Glucose infusions may precipitate Wernicke’s disease in a previously unaffected patient or cause a rapid worsening of an early form of the disease (as in this patient). For this reason, thiamine should be administered to all alcoholic patients requiring parenteral glucose.

The triad is (mnemonic - GOA):

  • Global Confusion
  • Ophthalmoplegia (first symptom to improve with thiamine +dextrose infusion)
  • Ataxia

Alcohol abuse leads to thiamine deficiency by the following mechanisms:

  • Poor nutritional habits
  • Folate deficiency which reduces thiamine absorption from the gastrointestinal tract
  • Direct damage of the intestinal mucosa

The initial treatment in a patient with Wernicke's disease should be emergent thiamine infusion, either IM or IV. This should be given daily until a normal diet is resumed and before treatment with IV glucose. Administration of glucose before thiamine can worsen Wernicke's encephalopathy.

questions.text: A patient came to OPD with complaints of passing loose bulky stools that were associated with abdominal pain for the past 2 weeks. Stool examination reveals an organism with 4 pairs of flagella exhibiting falling leaf motility. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and microscopy of an organism with 4 pairs of flagella and falling leaf motility is suggestive of giardiasis caused by Giardia lamblia.

Histopathology of the duodenum in giardiasis reveals several heart-shaped or pear-shaped trophozoites, with 2 equally sized nuclei and 4 pairs of flagella. It exhibits slow oscillating motility that resembles falling leaf motility. 

Giardia lamblia, also called Giardia duodenalis, is the causative agent of giardiasis. It is a common pathogenic protozoan found in the duodenum and jejunum of humans.

Infection occurs by the ingestion of mature cysts in contaminated water and food. and may also be transmitted by the fecal-oral route.

It is weakly pathogenic in humans. Hence, giardiasis usually occurs in immunosuppressed, agammaglobulinemia, or malnourished individuals.

Clinical features:

  • Diarrhea 
  • Fat malabsorption
  • Dull epigastric pain
  • Belching and flatulence
  • Iron deficiency and growth stunting.
  • The stool will have excess mucus and fat but no blood.

Detection of antigens by ELISA is more sensitive and specific than microscopy. Entero test /string test is also used in the diagnosis.

Other options:

Isospora belli is a coccidian parasite that can cause protracted diarrhea in immunocompromised patients. The oocyst is not easily seen on stool-wet mounts. It may be visible after stool concentration and staining with acid-fast stain, as shown below.

Cryptosporidium parvum, commonly causes diarrhea in immunocompromised individuals. The oocysts in the stool can be visualized by modified Ziehl-Neelsen staining. It appears as red acid-fast spheres. It can also be used for specimens such as sputum and bronchial wash. The image given below demonstrates uniformly acid-fast oocysts of Cryptosporidium parvum.

questions.text: A patient presents with urinary symptoms due to benign prostatic hyperplasia. Which of the following is used to manage the urinary symptoms in the initial stage of this condition?
questions.solution:
Tamsulosin is used for the management of urinary symptoms in the initial stages of Benign prostatic hyperplasia(BPH). It improves the urinary flow by inhibiting the smooth muscle contraction of the prostate thereby reducing the resistance at the bladder neck.

BPH is characterized by symptoms of urinary frequency, urgency, nocturia, incontinence, slow urinary stream, straining to void, urinary intermittency (stream starting and stopping during micturition), or hesitancy, splitting of the voiding stream, and terminal dribbling. Physical examination reveals a smooth enlarged and non-tender prostate. Lab investigations reveal a normal PSA (prostate-specific antigen). Diagnosis is made based on clinical presentation and a lack of lab findings suggestive of malignancy (elevated PSA). A biopsy is rarely indicated.

Conservative treatment is recommended for men with mild symptoms, flow rate >10ml/s, and good bladder emptying with residual urine <100ml. 

Medical management includes alpha-adrenergic blocking agents that inhibit the contraction of smooth muscle that is found in the prostate. Tamsulosin is an adrenoreceptor antagonist with receptor selectivity at α1A. It is used in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia.

The other class of drugs is the 5α-reductase inhibitors, which inhibit the conversion of testosterone to DHT, the most active form of androgen. Finasteride is a 5α-reductase enzyme inhibitor. It is effective in the treatment of palpable enlarged prostate. These drugs result in a 25% shrinkage of the prostate gland.

Indications for surgical management:

  • Lower urinary tract symptoms that are refractory to medical therapy
  • Refractory urinary retention
  • Recurrent urinary tract infection (UTI)
  • Hematuria
  • Stone formation
  • Hydronephrosis, hydroureter with renal functional impairment

Surgical management involves the use of the transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP). Laser ablative techniques using holmium YAG can also be done. 

Other options:

  • Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic medication that can help relax smooth muscles in certain parts of the body, but it is not specifically indicated for treating BPH-related symptoms. 

  • Finasteride: Finasteride belongs to a class of drugs known as 5-alpha-reductase inhibitors. It is used in the treatment of BPH to reduce the size of the prostate gland over time, but it may take several months of treatment for noticeable effects to occur.

  • Danazol: Danazol is primarily known for its use in treating endometriosis and certain other conditions, including hereditary angioedema. Danazol is not considered a first-line or typical therapy for BPH.

questions.text: A male patient presented with headache, nausea, vomiting, and diaphoresis since early morning. He was diagnosed with depression 4 months back and has been taking medication. He gives the history of attending an office party the previous night where he consumed some red wine. On examination, his BP was 190/120. Which of the following medications must have caused this presentation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cheese reaction.

Here, the patient was most probably on phenelzine (non-selective and irreversible MAO inhibitor) and developed the clinical features of cheese reaction on having tyramine-rich food (red wine, cheese, milk).

Phenelzine is a monoamine oxidase inhibitor that is used to treat MDD resistant to first and second-line antidepressants. It acts to prevent the degradation of serotonin and norepinephrine. The common adverse effect associated with this is a hypertensive crisis as seen with ingestion of tyramine-rich foods (cheeses). Inhibition of gastrointestinal MAO reduces the degradation of tyramine which then enters the systemic circulation and promotes catecholamine release. Other side effects are weight gain, sexual dysfunction, and suicidal thoughts.

The drug of choice to treat hypertensive crisis in cheese reactions is phentolamine. 

MAO-inhibitor with SSRI causes serotonin syndrome. Symptoms are fever, altered mental status, rigidity, hyperreflexia, and autonomic dysfunction.

Selegiline and rasagiline do not functionally inhibit MAO-A. They do not cause cheese reaction with doses used in clinical practice.

Other options:

  • Prazosin: Prazosin is an alpha-1 adrenergic receptor antagonist. It is commonly used to treat conditions like hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).  It is not known to cause hypertensive crises like the patient's presentation.

  • Phentolamine: Phentolamine is a non-selective alpha-adrenergic receptor antagonist. It is used in medical settings to treat hypertensive emergencies, such as those caused by excessive catecholamine release or drug interactions. In this case, phentolamine might be used to manage the hypertensive crisis caused by phenelzine and red wine.

  • Propranolol: Propranolol is a beta-blocker, and it works by blocking the effects of norepinephrine and other stress hormones. It is commonly prescribed to manage conditions like hypertension, angina, and certain types of arrhythmias.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male, with a known case of coronary artery disease, presented for a general check-up. On examination, vital signs are normal. He has notable long limbs. Blood glucose concentration is 100 mg/dL and homocysteine concentration is 20 μmol/L. Serum lipid levels are normal. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient in this patient?

Normal homocysteine concentration in blood = 5-15 μmol/L.
questions.solution:
This patient with long limbs, coronary artery disease and elevated homocysteine concentration most likely has homocystinuria, and the enzyme deficiency in this condition is cystathionine β synthase.

Homocystinuria is most commonly caused by a defect in the cystathionine β synthase enzyme leading to the accumulation of homocysteine in urine and blood. They are generally normal at birth and the first sign is subluxation of the lens (ectopia lentis) seen after 3 years of age.

Manifestations of homocystinuria:

  • Ectopia lentis.
  • Intellectual disability and psychiatric and behavioral disorders.
  • Thromboembolic episodes.
  • Skeletal abnormalities resembling those of Marfan syndrome: They are tall and thin with elongated limbs and arachnodactyly.

Elevations of both methionine and homocysteine in body fluids are the diagnostic lab findings.

Other Options:

  • Deficiency of homogentisate oxidase is associated with alkaptonuria.

  • Deficiency of Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRTase) is responsible for Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

Related Pearl: Homocystinuria

questions.text: A middle aged woman presents with complaints of hearing her own voice and breath sounds. On examination, the tympanic membrane was moving with respiration. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario where the patient hears her own voice and breath sounds is called autophony which is seen patulous eustachian tube.

Patulous eustachian tube is usually idiopathic where the tube is abnormally patent. But it is also seen in rapid weight loss, pregnancy especially the third trimester and patients with multiple sclerosis.

The eustachian tube valve is patulous and hence always open.This leads to the transfer of pressure changes in the nasal cavity to the middle ear and consequent movement of the tympanic membrane with respiration. This patent communication is the reason for hearing of own voice and breathing sounds

Treatment includes weight gain and administration of potassium iodide solution. In long-standing cases, specific treatment could include the cauterization of tubes or the insertion of the grommet.

Mass lesions of the nasal cavity may occlude the eustachian tube and cause fullness of the ear or otitis media, but won't cause any movement of tympanic membrane with respiration

questions.text: A newborn baby presents with difficulty breathing. It is noted that his symptoms improve when he cries. In which disease does the symptom improve upon crying?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario stridor in an infant that relieves on crying is suggestive of choanal atresia.

Improvement of stridor on crying is seen in gross obstruction like choanal atresia while laryngomalacia presents with worsening of stridor while crying or feeding. Sinusitis presents with stretor rather than stridor and it does not relieve while crying.

Choanal atresia is the persistence of the bucconasal membrane, unilateral is more common and may remain undiagnosed until adult life, bilateral atresia will present as a respiratory obstruction in the newborn. The initial clinical evaluation consists of placing a large laryngeal mirror under each nostril and checking for fogging, this is known as the laryngeal mirror test.

Diagnosis can be made by:

  • Presence of mucoid discharge in the nose
  • Absence of air bubbles in the nasal discharge
  • Failure to pass a catheter from the nose to the pharynx
  • Putting methylene blue dye into the nose and checking its passage to the pharynx
  • Putting a radio-opaque dye into the nose and taking a lateral radiograph
  • CT in the axial plane 

Management: In bilateral atresia, emergency treatment is to provide an airway, which is done by McGovern's technique- (a feeding tube with a large hole that provides a good oral airway), this removes the need for tracheostomy. Definitive treatment is correcting the atresia either by trans palatal or transnasal approach, which is usually done at one and a half years of age.

Related Pearl: Choanal atresia

  • It is due to the persistence of bucconasal membrane which separates primitive oropharynx from the primitive nasopharynx
  • Unilateral > bilateral
  • 30% of cases are bony and 70% are mixed
  • Unilateral cases may be asymptomatic and present in adult life
  • Bilateral cases are life-threatening and present with respiratory distress
  • Associated with CHARGE syndrome
    • C- Coloboma of the eye
    • H- Heart defects
    • A- Atresia of choana
    • R- Retarded growth and development
    • G- Genital anomalies
    • E- Ear anomalies and hearing loss.
  • CT scan is the best investigation

Image: Membranous, bilateral choanal atresia in a newborn

 

 

  • McGoverns technique- A feeding nipple with a large hole provides a good oral airway
  • Definitive treatment consists of correction of atresia by a trans-nasal or trans-palatal approach.

questions.text: A schoolboy presented with the following finding. He has a history of trauma to his upper arm in the past. Which nerve is most likely to be injured in this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows wrist drop and the radial nerve is commonly damaged in this condition.

It occurs because the radial nerve supplies the dorsiflexors of the wrist and digits and an injury to it lends them paralyzed. Other findings include numbness on the dorsoradial aspect of the hand , the dorsal aspect of the radial 3 1/2 digits and  over the anatomical stuff box. When there is compression in the axilla, radial nerve palsy is called Saturday night palsy. There is paralysis of the triceps, and weakness of the wrist and hand. 

Shaft of humerus fracture is one of the most common causes of radial nerve injury because of how its closely related to the nerve. Given below is the course of radial nerve

questions.text: A male presented with the following findings which he noticed when he woke up in the morning. There was no history of associated fever or rash. What is the drug of choice for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Bell's palsy and steroids are the drug of choice for Bell's palsy

Bell's palsy is a lower motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve and involves the ipsilateral side of the upper and lower halves of the face. Bell's palsy is idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis, or paresis of acute onset. The onset of Bell's palsy is fairly abrupt. 

If the patient attempts to close the eye, the eyeball would turn up and out - this is known as the Bell's phenomenon. Decreased tearing, hyperacusis, taste disturbances, otalgia, weakness of the facial muscles, poor eyelid closure, etc can be seen. When the patient smiles, the face becomes distorted and lateralizes to the side opposite the palsy. Flattening of the forehead and nasolabial fold on the side affected by palsy. 

Treatment of Bell's palsy involves prednisone 60-80 mg daily during the first 5 days and then tapered over the next 5 days. The use of artificial tears and covering the eye at night prevents corneal drying.

Approximately 85 to 95% of patients recover fully. The presence of incomplete paralysis in the first week is the most favourable prognostic sign. Recurrences are seen in some cases. Bell's palsy is a diagnosis of exclusion. All other possible causes of facial paralysis should be ruled out by investigation.

questions.text: Which of the following has GLUT-2 glucose transporter?
questions.solution:
Liver is the primary site for GLUT 2 glucose transporter

Although the kidney and small intestine has GLUT 2, only liver has GLUT 2 on the apical part of the cell.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child being evaluated in a primary health center is found to have disfigured lips due to constant biting, inability to walk, dystonia, spasticity, and choreoathetosis. He has been diagnosed with a deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase. Which of the following disorders does the patient most likely have?
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely to have Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. It is an X-linked disorder characterized by a complete deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). 

Developmental delays with hyperuricemia are typical of this syndrome. Symptoms are predominantly neurological and these include hypotonia and developmental delay which become apparent before the child is 4 months old. Dystonia appears before the child is 1 year old and progresses to a point where the child cannot attain milestones like crawling and walking. Involuntary movements such as choreoathetosis develop within the first few years of life. Pyramidal signs like spasticity and hyperreflexia can also be observed by then.

Self-injurious behavior is the hallmark of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. The most commonly noted ones include biting of lips, fingers, and cheeks, causing profound disfigurement. There might also be a history of aggressive behavior like pinching, spitting, grabbing, hitting, or verbally abusing. Nephrolithiasis and gouty arthritis occur due to hyperuricemia.

Increased serum uric acid (>8 mg/dL) is found. Blood investigations generally show features of megaloblastic anemia.

Allopurinol, a drug that blocks the conversion of hypoxanthine and xanthine to uric acid by inhibiting the xanthine oxidase enzyme, is the mainstay of treatment for hyperuricemia and its complications. Pyramidal signs such as spasticity can be managed with the use of benzodiazepines or baclofen. Physical rehabilitation with walking aids, and devices to maintain posture, help prevent deformities.

Behavioral symptoms are managed with psychiatric, and medical interventions.

Other options: 

Option B: Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome is characterized by a partial deficiency of HGPRT. It is also associated with hyperuricemia but there are no neurological complications associated with it.

Option C: Orotic aciduria type I is characterized by a deficiency of the enzymes orotate phosphoribosyltransferase and orotidylic acid decarboxylase.

Option D: Orotic aciduria type II is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme orotidylic acid decarboxylase.

questions.text: Which artery is most commonly affected in bleeding from the nose?
questions.solution:
The most commonly affected artery in bleeding from the nose is the sphenopalatine artery. It is called the artery of epistaxis because of the same

Arterial supply of lateral wall of nose is given

Sites of epistaxis

  • Little’s area: It is the site in 90% of the patients with epistaxis. Four arteries form a vascular plexus called “Kiesselbach’s plexus” in the antero-inferior part of the nasal septum just above the vestibule. It is more prone to finger nail trauma and the drying effect of air.
  • Above the level of middle turbinate: The bleeding usually occurs from the anterior and posterior ethmoidalvessels (internal carotid system).
  • Below the level of middle turbinate: The bleeding is from the branches of sphenopalatine artery.
  • Posterior part of the nasal cavity or the nasopharynx: The blood flows into the pharynx.
  • Woodruff’s venous plexus: It is the site of posterior epistaxis in adults and is situated inferior to the posterior end of inferior turbinate.
  • Diffuse: It is often indicative of general systemic disorders and blood dyscrasias.

The stepwise management of epistaxis:

  1. Pinching of the nose with thumb and index finger for about 5 minutes compresses the vessels of the Little’s area.
  2. Cauterization of the bleeding point with silver nitrate or electrocautery. This is done under topical anesthesia.
  3. Anterior nasal packing.
  4. Posterior nasal packing for which patients should be hospitalized.
  5. Endoscopic cauterization of the bleeding point. 
  6. Elevation of the mucoperichondrial flap and submucosal resection operation- for persistent and recurrent bleeds from the septum.
  7. Ligation of vessels. 

    The recommended hierarchy of ligation of vessels in a patient of epistaxis is Sphenopalatine artery → Internal maxillary artery→ External carotid artery → Anterior /posterior ethmoidal artery.

  8. Transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation (TESPAL) is done under topical anesthesia with sedation or under general anesthesia. It is effective in controlling refractory posterior bleeds.
  9. Embolization of the internal maxillary artery by an interventional radiologist, via femoral artery catheterization.

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV-positive​ patient presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the image below. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of the given clinical scenario is oral candidiasis.

Oral candidiasis or thrush is a patchy, pseudomembranous lesion that can be scraped off and it develops over the tongue, lips, gum, or palate. It is composed of epithelial cells, yeasts, and pseudohyphae.

It occurs in almost all individuals with AIDS. Other risk factors include high levels of glucose, cellular immunodeficiency, corticosteroids or antibiotics.

It is treated with topical nystatin, oral ketoconazole, or fluconazole.

Other options:

Option B: Hairy leukoplakia is a wart-like growth on the tongue, caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. It is commonly seen as a white lesion on the lateral side of the tongue and cannot be scraped off.

Option C: Lichen planus is a pruritic disease characterized by papules commonly seen over the flexor surfaces and trunk. Oral and vulvovaginal lesions may also occur. Oral lesions appear as lacy, white, and raised lesions.

Option D: Diphtheria is characterized by the presence of a grey pseudomembrane covering the tonsils and pharynx.

questions.text: A tuberculosis patient on treatment is non-compliant with initial therapy. Drug susceptibility showed resistance to rifampicin and isoniazid. He was started with the next-line drug that inhibits mycobacterial ATP synthesis. Which of the following can be the newly given drug?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the drug that inhibits mycobacterial ATP synthesis is bedaquiline.

Bedaquiline targets subunit c of the ATP synthase of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. This results in inhibition of the proton pump activity of the ATP synthase and causes a failure in the bacillary energy metabolism.

400 mg daily for 2 weeks followed by 200 mg three times a week thereafter is the regimen for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis. 

Other options:

Option A: Cycloserine inhibits the alanine racemase that converts L-alanine to D-alanine. This stops the reactions in which D-alanine is incorporated into mycobacterial bacterial cell wall synthesis. 

Option B: Ethionamide inhibits mycobacterial growth by inhibiting the activity of the enoyl-ACP reductase of fatty acid synthase II which is an inhA gene product. Isoniazid inhibits the same enzyme. 

Option D: Pretomanid is used in extensively drug-resistant and multi-drug-resistant TB. It inhibits mycolic acids and proteins synthesis of M. tuberculosis and in non-replicating persistent bacilli.

questions.text: A farmer presented with a traumatic ulcer in his right eye. Microscopy was done which showed septate hyphae. What is the likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The most likely causative agent based on the clinical features and microscopy showing septate hyphae given is Aspergillus. 

Aspergillus fumigatus is the most common pathogenic species. It can cause invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients. This can be due to prolonged treatment with steroids or retro-positive status. It starts as pneumonia, which can later spread to involve other organs. Voriconazole is the drug of choice.

Other manifestations include allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis where central bronchiectasis is usually seen. Aspergilloma and superficial infections like otomycosis or mycotic keratitis are the other presentations.

Histopathological examination of the tissue section shows characteristic septate hyphae with dichotomous branching at an acute angle. The hyphae stain poorly with hematoxylin and eosin, so periodic acid–Schiff (PAS) stain is used. 

Other methods for diagnosis include detection of galactomannan (Aspergillus cell-wall component) and culture isolation. Aspergillus fumigatus grows dark green colonies, while Aspergillus niger appears black. Yellow-green colonies are seen in case of Aspergillus flavus. Microscopic examination of colonies stained with lactophenol cotton blue would show septate hyphae and conidiophores. 

Other options:

Options A and B - Rhizopus and Mucor are zygomycetes that are responsible for mucormycosis. Non-septate, broad hyphae are seen on tissue samples stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

The image below shows broad aseptate and irregularly-branched non-septate hyphae of Mucor.

Option C - Candida, the causative agent for candidiasis, appear as budding gram-positive cells on wet films and smears. Mycelial forms suggest colonization. Culture colonies are creamy-white and have a yeasty odor. Candida albicans, the most commonly implicated pathogenic species, form chlamydospores on corn meal agar.

The image below shows candidal hyphae and chlamydospores.

questions.text: A mother brings her child to the pediatric outpatient department complaining of recurrent infections. On examination, her child has a length-for-age less than–2 standard deviations below the median. There is a history of improper feeding in the past. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A length-for-age less than –2 standard deviations (SD) below the median is called stunting according to WHO.

Classification of nutritional status depending on the anthropometry (height/length for age): 

Classification Criteria
Moderate stunting (or) moderate chronic malnutrition Height/length-for-age < –2 SD and > –3 SD
Severe stunting (or) severe chronic malnutrition Height/length-for-age < –3 SD

The nutritional status of a child is assessed in terms of anthropometry:

The World Health Organization (WHO) has established international standards for normal child growth from birth to 5 years of age. The normalization of the anthropometric measures is done in terms of z-scores (standard deviation scores). The anthropometric indicators are marked in a growth chart which is compared with a reference curve.

The anthropometric measures used are weight for age, height for age, weight for height, BMI, and mid-upper arm circumference.

  • Low weight for height, or wasting, indicates acute malnutrition. It is also mentioned as wasting.
  • High weight-for-height indicates overweight.
  • Low height-for-age, or stunting, indicates chronic malnutrition. This is the best indicator of long-term nutritional status in the pediatric population.
  • Low weight-for-age indicates acute or chronic malnutrition. It does not differentiate between wasting and stunting. Hence, it has limited clinical significance.

Other options:

Option A: To diagnose a child as underweight, weight for age charts are used. If the weight for the age of a child is less than -2 SD, then the child is said to be moderately underweight. If it is less than -3SD, it is called severe underweight.

Option B: A diagnosis of wasting can be made with mid-upper arm circumference measurements and weight for height. A weight for height below -2 SD is called moderate wasting. A mid-upper arm circumference of less than 115mm or weight for height below -3SD is called severe wasting.

Option C: Malnutrition refers to any deficiencies in the dietary intake of a person. Although it means both undernutrition and overnutrition, in practice it is used interchangeably with undernutrition.

Related Pearl: World Health Organization (WHO) classification of nutritional status of infants and children

Mid-upper arm circumference ≥115 mm and <125 mm

Bilateral pitting edema

Severely wasted Weight-for-height/length <-3 SD

SD - Standard deviation (from the median)

questions.text: A patient with diarrhea is diagnosed with cholera. The causative agent acts on which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
Cholera is caused by Vibrio cholerae and the toxin produced by this organism acts on GM1 ganglioside receptors.

Vibrio cholerae is a comma-shaped, gram-negative bacillus with darting motility. It has a single polar flagellum. It causes cholera, an acute diarrheal disease. It is marked by painless, profuse, watery diarrhea with flecks of mucus (rice water stools) associated with effortless vomiting. Pulmonary edema and arrhythmias are some of the complications. 

Infection is acquired by ingestion of contaminated food and water. The organisms produce an enterotoxin known as cholera toxin (CT). It has 1 A and 5 B subunits. The B subunit (binding units) fixes to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on jejunal epithelial cells. The A subunit dissociates into the A2 fragment, which attaches the A1 fragment to the B subunit. This results in prolonged accumulation of cAMP, which causes an outpouring of large amounts of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen. Ultimately, it results in profuse watery diarrhea. 

In addition to the cholera toxin, additional toxins such as zona occludens toxin and accessory cholera toxin are also produced. The former alters intestinal permeability by its action on intestinal epithelial cells.

The characteristic darting mobility and its hindrance by antiserum can be used for rapid microscopic diagnosis.

Fluid resuscitation by rice-based ORS is recommended. Medical management includes erythromycin or azithromycin.

Other options:

  • GM2 gangliosides are involved in the metabolism of gangliosides, and abnormalities in their metabolism can lead to diseases like Tay-Sachs disease.
  • The Gi protein-coupled receptor is a type of G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) that plays a role in signal transduction. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, including cell signaling and responses to various hormones and neurotransmitters.
  • GM3 gangliosides are another type of glycosphingolipid found in cell membranes, and are involved in various cellular processes.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a part of urban health care system?
questions.solution:
Subcenters are not a part of the urban healthcare system. Its seen only in rural health care system.

The urban healthcare system has a primary healthcare center or PHC at the primary level. It will be the first point for OPD (consultation), basic laboratory diagnosis, drug and contraceptive dispensing, and counseling about communicable and non-communicable disease. The first referral unit will be Urban CHCs. There are other referral centres like sub-district hospitals, district hospital. Referrals from these are taken up by medical colleges and super specialty hospitals
