questions.text: Two days after the administration of penicillin, a patient developed hemolysis due to antibodies produced against the drug. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is this?
questions.solution:
Development of antibodies resulting in hemolysis after penicillin administration is an example of a type II reaction. This is a drug-induced type II hypersensitivity reaction.

Penicillin in high doses can result in immune-mediated hemolysis via the hapten mechanism. In this, the drug attaches to surface of RBC membrane. Antibodies are produced that are targeted against this combination of penicillin and RBCs. 

Complement is activated by the attached antibody leading to the removal of red blood cells by the spleen.

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Hypersensitivity Reactions

Type

Immune Mechanisms

Histopathological lesions

Immediate
 hypersensitivity
(type I)

  • Anaphylaxis
  • Allergies
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Atopic dermatitis

Production of IgE antibody →immediate release of vasoactive amines from mast cells

Vascular dilatation, edema, smooth muscle contraction, mucus production, tissue injury, inflammation

Antibody-mediated hypersensitivity
(type II)

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Goodpasture syndrome

Production of IgG, IgM → binds to antigen on target cell or tissue → phagocytosis or lysis of target cell by activated complement or Fc receptors; recruitment of leukocytes

Phagocytosis and lysis of cells; inflammation;

Immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity
(type III)

  • SLE
  • Serum sickness
  • Arthus reaction

Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes → complement activation →recruitment of leukocytes by complement products and Fc receptors → release of enzymes and other toxic molecules

Inflammation, necrotizing vasculitis (fibrinoid necrosis)

Cell-mediated hypersensitivity
(type IV)

  • Contact dermatitis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Type 1 diabetes
  • Tuberculosis

Activated T lymphocytes →

1. Release of cytokines, inflammation, and macrophage activation

2. T-cell-mediated cytotoxicity

Perivascular cellular infiltrates; edema; granuloma formation; cell destruction

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersensitivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft

questions.text: A male presented with complains of decreased sexual desire. He was recently diagnosed with depression and started on a drug for the same. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) that is associated with the side effects of sexual dysfunction. 

Fluoxetine is used in the treatment of major depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder, bulimia and anorexia nervosa, generalized anxiety disorders, and premenstrual dysphoric disorder.

Other adverse effects include dry mouth, urinary retention, insomnia, GI disturbances, risk of suicidal behavior, and weight gain.

Adverse effects of specific antidepressants:

Drug

Side effect

Amitriptyline

sedation, antimuscarinic, hypotension, arrhythmia, seizures

Fluoxetine

Nausea, anorexia, loss of libido, insomnia

Trazodone

Sedative, priapism, hypotension

Bupropion

Seizures, mild tachycardia, hypertension

Mirtazapine

Sedative, increased appetite, weight gain

a. Complex I 1. Barbiturates
b. Complex II 2. BAL(British anti-lewisite)
c. Complex III 3. Antimycin
d. Complex IV 4. Cyanide
questions.solution:
BAL(British anti-lewisite) used as an antidote for arsenic poisoning blocks complex III of the electron transport chain.

Complexes of ETC Inhibitors
Complex I: NADH-Q oxidoreductase Piericidin, amobarbital, rotenone
Complex II: Succinate-Q reductase TTFA (thenoyltrifluoroacetone), carboxin, malonate
Complex III: Q- cyt c oxidoreductase BAL(British anti-lewisite), antimycin A
Complex IV: Cyt c oxidase Hydrogen sulfide, carbon monoxide, cyanide
 ATP synthase Oligomycin

Related Pearl: Electron transport chain: components and its inhibitors

questions.text: A 65-year-old trumpet player presents with hoarseness of voice, cough, and neck swelling as shown in the image below. The swelling increases in size on coughing and on performing Valsalva maneuver. On pressing the swelling, a gurgling sound is heard. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hoarseness of voice, cough, neck swelling that increases in size on coughing/Valsalva maneuver and a gurgling sound heard on pressing the swelling are suggestive of laryngocele.

Laryngocele is an air-filled cystic swelling in the neck due to dilatation of the saccule. It is more commonly seen in trumpet players, glass-blowers, or weight lifters due to a raised transglottic air pressure in these people. It can be classified into internal, external, or combined types of laryngocele.

  • Internal laryngocele is limited within the larynx and appears as distension of the false cord and aryepiglottic fold
  • External laryngocele has a distended saccule that herniates through the thyrohyoid membrane and appears as a swelling in the neck
  • Combined or mixed laryngocele has both internal and external laryngoceles as its components

Given below is a diagrammatic representation of laryngocele.

Laryngocele presents with hoarseness of voice, cough, and airway obstruction (if large). External laryngocele presents as a reducible swelling in the neck that increases in size on coughing or performing the Valsalva maneuver. On pressing the neck swelling, a gurgling sound is heard, indicating a positive Bryce's sign. Adult laryngoceles can be associated with carcinoma.

Diagnosis is based on an indirect laryngoscopy and CT scan. Internal laryngocele is managed by marsupialization and external laryngocele is managed by a surgical excision through an external neck incision.

Other options:

Option A- Thyroglossal cyst is a midline cystic swelling usually affecting younger children. It can also occur at any age. It arises from the thyroglossal duct and can occur anywhere along the course of the thyroglossal duct. This swelling moves along with tongue protrusion as the thyroglossal duct is attached to the foramen cecum at the base of the tongue. It is managed by performing a Sistrunk operation.

The below image shows a patient with a thyroglossal cyst.

Option C: Zenker's diverticulum is a pulsion diverticulum in which the pharyngeal mucosa is herniated through the Killian's dehiscence (a weak area between the 2 parts of the inferior constrictor). It usually occurs due to the uncoordinated contraction or the spasm of the cricopharyngeal sphincter during deglutition. Dysphagia is the predominant feature with a gurgling sound produced on swallowing. Regurgitation of undigested food and aspiration pneumonia are also seen. Barium swallow reveals the sac and its size.

The below image shows Zenker's diverticulum on barium swallow. 

Option D- Cystic hygroma occurs due to obstruction of the jugular lymph sac. It is most commonly seen in the posterior triangle of the neck. More than 90% of the cases occur before the age of 2 years. It can result in stridor, respiratory difficulty, or feeding problems. It is partially compressible and brilliantly transilluminant.

The below image shows cystic hygroma in a child.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding phase Ib of a cystometrogram?

choices.text: It is due to the elasticity of bladder
It is due to the plasticity the bladder has
The graph is flat due to the contractility of the bladder
Micturition occur at the start of Ib

questions.solution:
The true statement regarding phase Ib in the cystometrogram is that segment Ib is due to plasticity of the badder. Plasticity is the ability of an object to deform its shape without breaking.

Cystometrogram is a plot of intravesical pressure against the volume of fluid in the bladder. The curve shows three segments:

  • Ia- initial slight rise in pressure when the first increments in the volume are produced
  • Ib- long, nearly flat segment as further increments are produced
  • II- sudden, sharp rise in pressure as the micturition reflex is triggered.
  • The dotted line- pressure-volume relation if the micturition had not occurred.

The flatness of segment Ib is a demonstration of the law of Laplace. The law of Laplace states that the pressure (P) in a spherical viscus is equal to twice the wall tension (T) divided by the radius (R). This is expressed as P= 2T/R. In the blad­der, the tension increases as the bladder get filled. Since the radius also increases because of the plasticity of the bladder, there is only a slight increase in pressure until the bladder is relatively full.

The first urge to void is felt at a bladder volume of about 150 mL. A marked sense of fullness is felt at a bladder volume of 400ml.

Micturition reflex is the result of sensory signals from the stretch receptors in the bladder wall, which are conducted to the sacral segments of the cord through the pelvic nerves and then efferent signals conducts back again to the bladder through the parasympathetic nerve fibers.

The micturition reflex pathway is given below.

Other options:

Option A: Elasticity refers to the ability of an object to return to its original state after being deformed by an external force. Elasticity of bladder is responsible for the recoil shrinking of the bladder after micturition. 

Option C: Contractility is the ability to contract and increase the tension or decrease the length or dimensions. Contractility of the bladder is responsible for the voiding of urine. It doesn't contribute to the flat curve in Ib.

Option D: Voiding starts at the end of Ib and the start of II.

questions.text: A 39 year old patient presents to the OPD with complaints of pain over his ear lobule. He also complains of difficulty in eating food and the inability to close his eyes completely. On examination, there is a swelling below his ear.  Which of the following nerves is most likely to be involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of pain over the ear lobule, inability to close eyes, and difficulty in eating point toward an injury to the facial nerve. The swelling could possibly be a parotid swelling injuring the facial nerve. The course of facial nerve is given below

 

 

 

Nerve supply of external ear

Pinna

  • Greater/Great auricular nerve - medial surface and posterior part of lateral surface (lobule, posterior part of helix and anti helix).
  • Lesser occipital nerve - upper part of medial surface.
  • Auriculotemporal nerve - tragus, crus of helix and adjacent part of helix.
  • Auricular branch of vagus (Arnold's nerve or Alderman's nerve) - concha on the lateral surface and post auricular groove medially.
  • Facial nerve - concha and post auricular groove along with Arnold's nerve.

External Auditory Canal

  • Auriculotemporal nerve - anterior wall and roof
  • Auricular branch of vagus - posterior wall and floor
  • Facial nerve - sensory supply to the posterior wall through the vagus

 Tympanic Membrane

  • Auriculotemporal nerve - anterior half of lateral surface
  • Auricular branch of vagus - posterior half of lateral surface
  • Tympanic branch of Glossopharyngeal - medial surface

questions.text: A girl with intellectual disability presents to the OPD with the following finding (image below). Cardiac evaluation shows a congenital endocardial cushion defect. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows simian crease. The clinical features of intellectual disability, congenital endocardial cushion defect point towards Down's syndrome

Down’s syndrome is an autosomal disorder. It was described by Langdon Down in 1866. It is also called trisomy 21 or mongolism. The clinical features of Down's syndrome seen in older children are: (Mnemonic: I C A PROBLEM Somewhere)

  • Intellectual disability/Incurved or short fifth finger with clinodactyly
  • Congenital heart disease
  • Acute megakaryoblastic leukaemia/Alzheimer's disease/Atlantoaxial instability/Atresia of the duodenum
  • Protruding tongue
  • Round face
  • Occiput flat/Open wide fontanelle/Open mouth
  • Brachycephalic/Brushfield's spots
  • Low (depressed) nasal bridge
  • Epicanthal fold/Ears low set and dysplastic
  • Mongoloid slant (oblique palpebral fissure)
  • Simian palmar crease and wider gap between first and second toes

 Image: A child having features of Down’s syndrome

Image: Brushfield's spots

Simian crease is also seen in:

  • Fetal alcohol syndrome
  • Trisomy 13
  • Cri du chat syndrome

questions.text: At what time during the intrauterine life does talus ossification center appear?
questions.solution:
The talus bone ossification center appears in the 6th month of intrauterine life.

Nearly all secondary centers commence ossification after birth, although a few develop in the last few weeks of intrauterine life. Secondary ossification centers that are already present when an infant is born include:

  • Distal femur - 7th week
  • Proximal tibia - 7th week
  • Humerus - 8th week
  • Calcaneus - 3 to 4th month
  • Talus - 6th month
  • Cuboid - 9th month

Forensic medicine textbooks like Knight's Forensic Pathology (4th edition page 456), The essentials of Forensic medicine and Toxicology
Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy (34th edition page 75) states that the talus ossification begins at 7 months instead of 6th.

The answer is as per Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice (42nd Edition page 1436)

questions.text: In a study about the age of a small population, the highest value 36 was mistakenly recorded as 63. What will happen to the mean and median of the data?

choices.text: Median will increase, mean will remain the same
Mean will increase, median will remain the same
Both mean and median will increase
Neither mean nor median will increase

questions.solution:
When the highest recorded value is replaced by a bigger value, mean will increase while median will be unaffacted

Median

  • The median is the central element in a distribution when all the elements are arranged in order.
  • In a distribution that has an odd number of elements, the median is the middle value.
  • In a distribution that has an even number of elements, the median is the average of the middle values, i.e., the arithmetic mean of the two middle values.
  • The median is not sensitive to extreme values, i.e., outliers and thus it is preferred measure of location for very skewed distributions.
  • The drawback of the median is that it doesn’t respond to the actual values of the elements but only to the number of values above or below
  • The median is the same as the 50th centile.
  • It is sometimes symbolized by Mdn.
  • The median can be arrived at in ordinal, interval and ratio data scales.

Related Pearl: The Mean (Arithmetic) in Biostatistics

  • The mean is also called the average or arithmetic mean.
  • It is the sum of all elements in the distribution divided by the number of all the elements in it.
  • It is usually denoted by μ in a population and by x̄ (x-bar) in a sample.
  • The formula for sample mean is given as:

where the sigma sign denotes summation and n is the total number of elements.

  • The arithmetic mean responds to the exact value of every element in the distribution.
  • This makes it over-sensitive to extreme values, i.e., outliers thus making it an inappropriate measure for skewed distributions.
  • The advantage of the arithmetic mean is that if repeated samples are taken from the same populations, they will have very similar means, i.e., the measure of central tendency that best resists the influence of fluctuation between samples is the mean.
  • The mean can be calculated only on quantitative data on an interval or a ratio scale.

questions.text: What is the vertebral level of the plane between the highest points of the iliac crests?
questions.solution:
The plane passing through the highest point of the iliac crest is called the supracristal plane. 

Posteriorly, it corresponds to the level of the L4 body or L4/5 disc and its spinous process

Related Pearl: Abdominal planes and their landmarks

Planes that divide the abdomen into 9 regions

  • Horizontal planes 
    • L3 - Subcostal plane (between 10th costal cartilages). Corresponds to the 3rd part of the duodenum
    • L5 - Transtubercular plane (between tubercles of iliac crests). Corresponds to the origin of Inferior vena cava. 
  • Vertical planes (Paramedian or lateral planes)
    • Mid-clavicular point to mid-inguinal point on both sides 

The nine regions of the abdomen include:

  • Left hypochondriac, Epigastric, Right hypochondriac
  • Left lumbar, Umbilical (Central), Right lumbar
  • Left iliac, Hypogastric (Suprapubic), Right iliac

Other planes and angles in the abdomen

  • Transpyloric (Addison's) plane passes midway between the suprasternal notch and the upper border of the pubic symphysis.
  • The supracristal plane passing through the highest point of the iliac crest on both sides. Posteriorly, it corresponds to the level of the L4 body or L4/5 disc and its spinous process. It is an important landmark when performing a lumbar puncture or spinal injection. The bifurcation of the abdominal aorta lies approximately in this plane.
  • The plane of the pubic crest passes through the upper border of the pubic symphysis. When supine, this plane intersects the tip of the coccyx and the femoral head.
  • Renal angle is the angle between the 12th rib and the outer border of Erector spinae muscle. The lower border of normal kidneys may occasionally be felt here. 
  • Lumbar triangle (of Petit) is marked below by the iliac crest, anteriorly by external oblique and posteriorly by latissimus dorsi. Lumbar herniation can occur here.

questions.text: The number of births per 1,000 women in the reproductive age group is called?
questions.solution:
Number of live births per 1000 women in the reproductive age group (15 - 49 years) in a given year is called the general fertility rate

  • GFR = Number of live births in an area in a year x 1000/Mid-year population of women in reproductive age in the same area in the same year.
  • It is a better indicator of fertility than crude birth rate
  • The demerit of this indicator is that not all women in the denominator are exposed to childbirth

 

Related Pearl: Fertility Indicators

Crude birth rate

  • It is the simplest measure of fertility although its usage is unsatisfactory
  • India, as per SRS bulletin 2018, had a birth rate of 20.0 per 1000 population

General Fertility Rate

  • It is a better indicator of fertility than crude birth rate
  • The demerit of this indicator is that not all women in the denominator are exposed to childbirth

Age-specific fertility rates is a more precise measure of fertility and is also a sensitive indicator of family planning achievement.

Total Fertility Rate

  • It is the sum of all age-specific fertility rates multiplied by 5
  • This measure gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size

Gross Reproductive Rate is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.

Net Reproduction Rate

  • It is a demographic indicator
  • NRR of 1 is equivalent to approximately the 2 child norm
  • If the NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be inadequate

questions.text: A newly diagnosed HIV patient presented with fever, cough, and hemoptysis. What is the investigation of choice to test for TB in this patient?
questions.solution:
As per RNTCP guidelines, CBNAAT is the preferred diagnostic technique for testing TB in PLHIV (people living with HIV). Smear microscopy has poor sensitivity in detecting TB in PLHIV due to fewer organisms in sputum, and hence is not preferred.

Tuberculosis is the most common opportunistic infection in people living with HIV AIDS. The combined treatment of both TB and HIV has found to have profound impact on mortality. The main stay of treatment is to start ATT first and then start ART as soon as ATT is tolerated (between 2 weeks and 2 months) by the patient. This is done in order to avoid immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS). 

Patients with HIV-related TB may experience a temporary paradoxical exacerbation of symptoms and radiographic manifestations of TB after starting ATT. This occurs as a result of immune reconstitution due to simultaneous administration of ART and ATT.

questions.text: A patient undergoing chemotherapy was given an antiemetic, after which he developed symptoms like acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors. Which of the following drugs would have caused these symptoms?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the patient has developed extrapyramidal adverse effects like acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors. This is likely due to the antagonist action on dopamine receptors by metoclopramide.

Metoclopramide is a prokinetic and antiemetic. It has the following pharmacological actions:

  • Dopamine receptor antagonist 
  • Serotonin (5HT4) receptor agonist 
  • Serotonin (5HT3) antagonist
  • Sensitization of muscarinic receptors on smooth muscle. This results in increased lower esophageal sphincter tone and stimulates gastric antral contractions.

Metoclopramide acts on both the gastrointestinal system and central nervous system. It is used as an upper antiemetic for many types of vomiting, especially migraine, drug-induced, and chemotherapy-induced. It is also used as a prokinetic in gastroparesis to increase gastric emptying.

Adverse effects of metoclopramide are mainly extrapyramidal effects, and these include acute dystonia, Parkinson-like symptoms (tremors, bradykinesia, rigidity), tardive dyskinesia, galactorrhea due to hyperprolactinemia, and methemoglobinemia in neonates.

Extrapyramidal symptoms can be treated by discontinuation of metoclopramide and administration of anticholinergics or antihistaminics.

Other options:

Option A: Ondansetron is a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist. It blocks impulses at the peripheral origin in GIT. It is most commonly indicated for the treatment of postoperative and chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. Headache and dizziness are the common adverse effects.

Option C: Meclizine is a long-acting H1 antihistaminic drug. It is used for seasickness. It is less sedative and less anticholinergic.

Option D: Scopolamine (hyoscine) is a muscarinic antagonist. It blocks neural pathways from the vestibular apparatus in the inner ear to the emetic center in the brainstem. A transdermal patch of scopolamine is used as an antiemetic in motion sickness. Constipation, drowsiness, dry mouth, and blurred vision are the common adverse effects.

questions.text: Which of the following methods would you employ for initial feeding in a neonate born at 29 weeks of gestation?

choices.text: IV fluids plus occasional paladai feeds
Orogastric tube feeds plus occasional paladai feeds

questions.solution:
Best method for initial feeding in a neonate born at 29 weeks of gestation is orogastric tube feeds plus occasional paladai feeds

The feeding of neonates depends on their gestational age and it depends on the level of maturity of the neonate. Based on birth weight, babies can be classified into

  • Low birth weight (LBW) - Birth weight < 2.5kg
  • Very low birth weight (VLBW)- Birth weight <1.5kg
  • Extremely low birth weight (ELBW)- Birth weight <1kg

All LBW infants, irrespective of their initial feeding method should receive only breast milk. This can be given as expressed breast milk (mothers' own milk) to those infants fed by paladai or gastric tube. An alternative is human donor milk. When there is a contraindication to breastfeeding or if the mother is sick, formula feeds can be given. Term formula feed in babies with birth weight >1500 g and preterm formula feed in VLBW babies can be given. All hemodynamically stable LBW babies should receive Kangaroo mother care(KMC).

 

Related Pearl: Choice of initial feeding method in LBW infants

The feeding of neonates depends on their gestational age and it depends on the level of maturity of the neonate. 

Gestational Age Feeding Skill Matured Method of Feeding
 <28 weeks No proper sucking effort. No propulsive motility of the gut  Intravenous Fluids
 28-31 weeks

Sucking bursts develop

No coordination between suck/swallow and breathing

 Routine oro-gastric/ Nasogastric tube feeding with occasional spoon/ paladai feeding
 32-34 weeks The sucking pattern begins to mature. Coordination between breathing and swallowing begins  Feeding by spoon/paladai/cup
 >34 weeks Mature sucking pattern present. Better coordination between breathing and swallowing  Breastfeeding

questions.text: A child presents with a fever and continuing seizures for the past 30 minutes. The relatives say that there had been no seizure-free intervals in the past 30 minutes. What is the next best step to manage this patient?

choices.text: Manage the fever and wait for seizure to subside
Manage the airway and wait for seizure to subside

questions.solution:
This scenario described above is of status epilepticus. The first line drug used is IM midazolam or IV Diazepam/Lorazepam.

Status epilepticus refers to continuous or repetitive, discrete seizures with impaired consciousness which lasts for more than 5 minutes.

The duration of seizure activity to meet the definition of status epilepticus has traditionally been specified as 15–30 min. However, a more practical definition is to consider status epilepticus as a situation in which the duration of seizures prompts the acute use of anticonvulsant therapy, i.e., more than 5 minutes.

Management of status epilepticus:

questions.text: Healthcare workers should be vaccinated against ________.
questions.solution:
Healthcare workers should be vaccinated against Hepatitis B.

These are most likely to be transmitted by the handling of biomedical waste.

Yearly health check-ups should be done, and a booster dose should be given if needed.

Post-exposure prophylaxis for HBV:

When the Hepatitis B status of the source patient is unknown: HCW is managed as if the source patient were HBsAg-positive.

When the source patient is HBV-positive:

  • HCW whose response is unknown after one round of HBV vaccination - HBIG (hepatitis B hyperimmune globulin) 0.06 ml/kg as soon as possible, preferably within 24 hours and should simultaneously reinitiate the course of HBV immunization with three doses of hepatitis B vaccine.
  • HCW is a non-responder after two rounds of HBV vaccination - HBIG (hepatitis B hyperimmune globulin) 0.06 ml/kg as soon as possible, preferably within 24 hours and a second dose of HBIG, 1 month after the first dose.
  • Healthcare worker (HCW) is immunized and a responder (anti-HBs antibodies >10 mIU/ml) - They are protected. No need for hepatitis B immunoglobulin after a potential or confirmed exposure to hepatitis B.
  • HCW is incompletely vaccinated/unvaccinated - HBIG (hepatitis B hyperimmune globulin) 0.06 ml/kg as soon as possible, preferably within 24 hours and should simultaneously start/reinitiate the course of HBV immunization with three doses of hepatitis B vaccine.

Follow-up: After the three-dose vaccination series is completed, antibodies to the surface antigen is checked 1–2 months later. If the titres are <10 mIU/ml a second three-dose vaccine series is started or the HCW is checked for HBsAg positivity. 

Some other vaccines that are given to healthcare workers include:

  • Tetanus-diphtheria-pertussis (Tdap) vaccine
  • Measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine
  • Influenza vaccine
  • Varicella (chickenpox) vaccine
  • Human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine

questions.text: A male develops tightness in the chest, associated with breathlessness and altered sensorium during his trek towards a mountain peak. The drug prescribed for symptomatic relief acts of which part of the nephron?
questions.solution:
The symptoms are suggestive of acute mountain sickness and acetazolamide can be given for symptomatic relief. It acts on the proximal convoluted tubule.

Acetazolamide, a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, acts on the enzyme in epithelial cells of the proximal convoluted tubule. By inhibiting carbonic anhydrase, HCO3- reabsorption is blocked and diuresis occurs.

Acetazolamide (125–250 mg twice a day), administered for 1 day before ascent and continued for 2 or 3 days is very effective. It can also be used for prophylaxis. Paresthesia and a tingling sensation are common side effects of acetazolamide. Bone marrow depression is rare but a serious side effect. It is contraindicated in liver disease.

Acute mountain sickness:

When individuals arrive first at a high, altitude, many develop transient 'mountain sickness'. This syndrome develops 8-24 hours after arrival at altitude and lasts 4-8 days.

Characterized by:

  • Headache
  • Irritation
  • Insomnia
  • Breathlessness
  • Nausea and vomiting

Cause: Appears to be associated with cerebral edema

The low PO2 at high altitudes causes arteriolar dilation, and if cerebral autoregulation does not compensate, there is an increase in capillary pressure that favours increased transudation of fluid into brain tissue leading to cerebral edema. In high-altitude cerebral edema, the capillary leakage in mountain sickness progresses to frank brain swelling, with ataxia, disorientation, and in some cases coma and death due to herniation of the brain through the tentorium.

Treatment:

  • Descent to a lower altitude
  • Diuretics like acetazolamide: inhibits carbonic acid anhydrase, and results in stimulated respiration, increased PaCO2, and reduced formation of CSF
  • Glucocorticoids are administered as well. Their mechanism of action is not clear.

questions.text: A study was conducted on a group of people to study the factors that increase and inhibit the secretion of insulin. Which of the following factors inhibit its secretion?
questions.solution:
Epinephrine decreases insulin secretion, whereas all others- acetylcholine, gastric inhibitory polypeptide, and glucagon stimulate insulin secretion. 

One of the most important inhibitors of insulin secretion is α adrenergic system. They act via epinephrine and norepinephrine on the secretion of insulin when glucose deficiency is detected.

Insulin is secreted by the pancreatic beta cells in response to increased blood glucose concentration. It promotes liver uptake, storage, and the utilization of glucose from the blood. If blood glucose levels are high, they cause glucose to be rapidly stored in the liver in the form of glycogen. It also promotes the conversion of this excess glucose to fatty acids. When glucose levels fall, insulin secretion is decreased and activation of enzyme phosphorylase split glycogen to release stored glucose into the circulating blood. 

Mechanism of insulin secretion:

Glucose enters beta cells of the pancreas via GLUT-2 receptors. Once inside, it is phosphorylated by glucokinase (rate-limiting step) to glucose-6-phosphate which is oxidized to form adenosine triphosphate (ATP). This ATP causes the closure of ATP-sensitive potassium channels and hence depolarization. This leads to opening voltage-gated calcium channels and Ca2+ influx. This stimulates the fusion of the insulin-containing vesicles with the cell membrane and the secretion of insulin into the extracellular fluid by exocytosis.

Related Pearl: Factors affecting insulin secretion

Glucose

Mannose

Mannoheptulose

Glucagon

Amino acids - leucine arginine

Intestinal hormones - GIP, GLP-1, gastrin, secretin, CCK

Leptin

Theophylline

questions.text: A female patient presents with complaints of pain over the anterolateral aspect of thigh after normal vaginal delivery. Which is the nerve injured in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with symptoms of pain over the anterolateral aspect of the thigh is suggestive of meralgia paresthetica. It is due to compression neuropathy or neuroma of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve of the thigh. 

The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh arises from the posterior divisions of the ventral rami of L2 and L3, and it supplies the skin of the anterior and lateral surfaces of the thigh up to the knee.

It is prone to injury especially as it leaves the pelvis deep to the inguinal ligament just medial to the anterior superior iliac spine. The angulation of the nerve as it crosses the iliac crest makes it vulnerable to compression during hip extension which may increase angulation and tension on the nerve. This leads to impaired sensation, pain and paraesthesia on the anterolateral aspect of thigh, in the distal end of the cutaneous distribution of this nerve. The symptoms don't cross the midline, nor extend below knee or behind hamstrings laterally

 

Related Pearl: Compression of different nerves and their syndromes

Syndrome

Pronator teres syndrome

Median nerve (proximally compressed beneath ligament of Struthers, bicipital aponeurosis, or origins of pronator teres)

Radial tunnel (Arcade of Frohse) syndrome

Posterior Interosseous nerve (in proximal forearm)

Cubital tunnel syndrome

Ulnar nerve behind medial epicondyle

Cheiralgia Paresthetica (Wartenburg syndrome)

Superficial sensory branch of radial nerve

Carpal tunnel syndrome

Median nerve (at wrist)

Guyon's canal syndrome

Ulnar nerve(at wrist)

Thoracic outlet syndrome

Lower trunk of brachial plexus

Tarsal tunnel syndrome

Piriformis syndrome

Sciatic nerve

Mortons Metatarsalgia Interdigital plantar nerve

questions.text: While performing a caloric test, what type of nystagmus would you expect on cold water irrigation?

choices.text: Horizontal nystagmus towards the same side
Vertical nystagmus towards the same side
Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side
Vertical nystagmus towards the opposite side

questions.solution:
In caloric testing, cold water irrigation produces horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side.

Fitzgerald–Hallpike test/bithermal caloric test:

  • In this test, the patient lies supine with head tilted 30° forward so that the horizontal canal is vertical.
  • Ears are irrigated for 40 seconds alternatively with water at 30°C and at 44°C (i.e., 7° below and above normal body temperature) and eyes are observed for the appearance of nystagmus till its endpoint.
  • Time taken from the start of irrigation to the end point of nystagmus is recorded and charted on a calorigram.
  • If no nystagmus is elicited from any ear, the test is repeated with water at 20°C for 4 min before labeling the labyrinth dead.
  • A gap of 5 min should be allowed between two ears.

Cold water induces nystagmus to the opposite side and warm water to the same side (remember mnemonic COWS: cold–opposite, warm–same).

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department soon after a road traffic accident with intense superficial pain due to injuries. Which nerve fibre is responsible for the conduction of this pain?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of acute superficial pain refers to fast pain or first pain. It is transmitted by A delta (δ) fibers.

Pain can be carried by either Aδ fiber (fast pain/ epicritic pain) or by C fiber (slow pain/protopathic pain)

Fast pain is a rapid response and mediates the ability to localize the site and intensity of the noxious stimulus. it occurs when glutamate is released following the stimulation of A delta fibers.

Slow pain on the other hand can also be burning, dull and poorly localized. It is transmitted by C nociceptor fibers which release substance P.

Other options :

Option A: Aα is seen in muscle spindle and Golgi tendon organs and is associated with proprioception. They have the thickest fibre and fastest connection velocity. They are the Ia and Ib fibres in numerical classification

Option B: Aβ is associated with touch and pressure conduction and is seen in conjunction with flower-spray ending. In numerical classification, they correspond to II fibres.

Option D: C fibres (dorsal root) are associated with pain and temperature with a conduction velocity of 0.5-2 m/s while C fibres (sympathetic) carry the postganglionic sympathetic function and conduct at a velocity of 0.7-2.3 m/s.
